The '''Cleveland sports curse''' was a [[Sports-related curses|sports superstition]] involving the city of [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], and its [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major league professional sports teams]], centered on the failure to win a [[championship]] in any major league sport for a period of 52 years, from 1964 to 2016. Three major league teams based in Cleveland contributed to belief in the curse: the [[Cleveland Browns|Browns]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL); the [[Cleveland Cavaliers|Cavaliers]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA); and the [[Cleveland Indians|Indians]] of [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB). Combined with the short-lived [[Cleveland Barons (NHL)|Barons]] franchise of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL), Cleveland teams endured an unprecedented 147-season championship [[drought (sports)|drought]], having not won a title since the Browns defeated the [[Baltimore Colts]] in the [[1964 NFL Championship Game]] two seasons prior to the first [[Super Bowl]].<ref name="MostCursedSportsCities">{{cite news|author=The Upshot Staff|title=The Most Cursed Sports Cities in America|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/06/04/upshot/The-Most-Cursed-Sports-Cities-in-America.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 4, 2015|accessdate=June 22, 2016}}</ref>
Cleveland's 52-year championship drought finally ended when the Cavaliers beat the [[Golden State Warriors]] in Game 7 of the [[2016 NBA Finals]], an event widely interpreted as having broken the curse.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCauley|first=Janie|title=James and Cavaliers win thrilling NBA Finals Game 7, 93-89|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160619/CLEGSW/gameinfo.html|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=May 18, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Tan|first=Avianne|title=This Cavs Season Ticket Holder Waited 45 Years for a Championship|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/meet-69-year-cleveland-cavaliers-fan-bought-season/story?id=40014126|work=[[ABC News]]|publisher=ABC News Internet Ventures|date=June 21, 2016|accessdate=July 12, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Broken 1"/><ref name="Broken 2"/><ref name="Broken 3"/><ref name="Broken 4"/>
==Cleveland Browns== {{Further|Red Right 88|The Drive|The Fumble|Cleveland Browns relocation controversy}}
Much of the discussion of the "curse" is centered on the NFL's [[Cleveland Browns]], who have not won a [[History of the National Football League championship|championship]] since 1964 and have suffered a series of questionable coaching decisions, disappointing losses and draft busts.
Prior to [[Art Modell]] becoming majority owner of the team, the Browns had dominated the NFL and the earlier [[All-America Football Conference]] (AAFC), winning seven championships in 17 years. After three non-playoff seasons, the [[1964 Cleveland Browns season|1964 Browns' team]] finished 10–3–1 and appeared in the [[1964 NFL season|1964 NFL Championship Game]] against a heavily favored [[History of the Indianapolis Colts|Baltimore Colts]] team coached by [[Don Shula]] with [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] quarterback [[Johnny Unitas]] as its signal caller. The Browns beat the Colts 27–0 at [[Cleveland Stadium]]. This particular Browns team consisted of many players initially drafted and acquired by [[Paul Brown]], the Browns' former long-time head coach and architect of the team's earlier successes, who had been fired by Modell early in 1963. During the next 30 years in Cleveland, not a single Modell team won the league or conference title, although they did appear in a total of seven NFL/[[American Football Conference]] (AFC) championship title games during the period.
In 1981, trailing by two points to the [[1980 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] and in field goal range with less than one minute remaining in the [[1980–81 NFL playoffs#AFC Championship: Oakland Raiders 34, San Diego Chargers 27|AFC divisional playoff game]], the Browns executed a passing play that was intercepted in the end zone. The play, called by Browns head coach [[Sam Rutigliano]], has become known as "[[Red Right 88]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Tioseco|first=Raymond J.|url=http://www.raiders.com/news/article-1/Greatest-Moments-1980-AFC-Divisional-Playoff/d85d64d5-6ffb-4f04-9321-bf85b95dacb5|title=Greatest Moments: 1980 AFC Divisional Playoff|publisher=Oakland Raiders|date=January 4, 2014|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref>
In the [[1986–87 NFL playoffs]], the Browns were one game away from playing in what would have been the franchise's first Super Bowl when they fell short in one of the most memorable games in NFL history. The Browns were leading the [[1986 Denver Broncos season|Denver Broncos]] 20–13 in the fourth quarter when Broncos quarterback [[John Elway]] led a 98-yard game-tying drive in just over 5 minutes. The game went to overtime, and the Broncos kicked a field goal to seal the victory. Elway's fourth quarter march and the game itself became known as "[[The Drive]]", a title that both signifies Elway's brilliance in the clutch and the Browns' inability to close out important games.
The Browns and Broncos both returned to the AFC Championship Game the next year. With the Browns down 38–31 late in the fourth quarter, Browns' running back [[Earnest Byner]] was handed the ball near the goal line. Byner, who was in the midst of a great performance, was stripped of the ball and the Broncos recovered on their 2-yard line. The Broncos surrendered an intentional safety and went on to win 38–33, while Byner's blunder became known as "[[The Fumble]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Simmons|first=Bill|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=simmons/100129&sportCat=nfl|title=Consider these teams officially tortured|publisher=''ESPN''|date=January 29, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref>
The Browns returned to the AFC Championship game in the 1989–90 season, again [[1989–90 NFL playoffs#AFC Championship: Denver Broncos 37, Cleveland Browns 21|losing to the Broncos]]. As of the [[2017 NFL season]], the Browns have not returned to the AFC Championship Game since and remain one of four teams to never play in a Super Bowl, along with the [[Detroit Lions]], [[Houston Texans]], and [[Jacksonville Jaguars]].
The Browns were at the center of a [[Cleveland Browns relocation controversy|relocation controversy]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dyer|first=Bob|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Ss1kgr1u-EC&lpg=PA6&dq=%22the%20move%22%20%22the%20shot%22%20cleveland%20browns&pg=PA277#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Top 20 Moments in Cleveland Sports History: Tremendous Tales of Heroes and Heartbreaks|publisher=Gray & Company|pages=277–291|isbn=9781598510300|year=2007|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> The decision by then-Browns owner [[Art Modell]] to move the Browns, which had been an 11–5 team the [[1994 Cleveland Browns season|previous season]], to [[Baltimore]] infuriated and confused Browns fans.<ref name=brcurse>{{cite web|last=Folsom|first=Jim|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/392399-the-ultimate-sports-curse-the-city-of-cleveland|title=The Ultimate Sports Curse: The City of Cleveland|publisher=''[[Bleacher Report]]''|date=May 15, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> After negotiations with the NFL and the city of Cleveland, Modell was allowed to move the team's personnel to Baltimore, where it became a new franchise known as the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. The Ravens won a [[Super Bowl XXXV|Super Bowl]] in only their fifth year of existence, doing so with former Browns tight end [[Ozzie Newsome]] as their general manager. In addition to Newsome's success, coach [[Bill Belichick]], who was fired as Browns' head coach soon after the 1995 season,<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2202&dat=19960215&id=2xEmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yf0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6697,1482003&hl=en | title=Modell fires Bill Belichick | work=[[The Gettysburg Times]] | location=[[Gettysburg, Pennsylvania]] | date=February 15, 1996 | accessdate=October 6, 2017}}</ref> became head coach of the [[New England Patriots]] five years later. With the Patriots, Belichick has coached only one losing season and won eight AFC Championships and five Super Bowls. The struggles of the Browns since rejoining the NFL, as well as the success of both Newsome and Belichick, were chronicled in the NFL Films feature ''[[A Football Life]]'': 1995 Cleveland Browns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Story of 1995 Cleveland Browns Detailed on NFL Network’s ‘Cleveland ’95: A Football Life’|url=https://nfllabor.wordpress.com/2012/09/28/story-of-1995-cleveland-browns-detailed-on-nfl-networks-cleveland-95-a-football-life/|publisher=NFL Communications|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref>
The Browns returned to the NFL in 1999, after a three-year period of deactivation. In the [[1999 NFL Draft]], the Browns selected [[Tim Couch]], hoping he would be a franchise quarterback. [[Ty Detmer]] was brought in to usher in the planned "Couch era", but after a string of dismal performances, Couch was rushed into the starting position.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wassink|first=Zac|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/cleveland-browns-had-19-starting-quarterbacks-since-1999-220000982--nfl.html|title=The Cleveland Browns Have Had 19 Starting Quarterbacks Since 1999|publisher=''Yahoo! Sports''|date=September 18, 2013|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> Couch struggled to perform without a talented roster around him, which led to his eventual departure from the Browns after the 2003 season. Although only winning 22 games in 59 starts, Couch led the Browns to their only playoff berth since their return, in 2002.
By the end of the 2017 season, the Browns had started 28 different quarterbacks since their 1999 return to the NFL, a league-high in that period.<ref>{{cite web|last=Friedman|first=Matt|url=http://returnofcleveland.com/2014/01/14/ranking-the-20-cleveland-browns-starting-quarterbacks-since-1999/|title=Ranking The 20 Cleveland Browns Starting Quarterbacks Since 1999|publisher=''Return of Cleveland''|date=January 14, 2014|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Sprow | first=Chris | url=http://insider.espn.go.com/nfl/draft2014/story/_/id/10496424/cleveland-browns-succeed-2014-rookie-quarterback-nfl | title=Browns can win with a rookie QB | work=ESPN | date=February 23, 2014 | accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> The Browns have not won a playoff game since [[1994–95 NFL playoffs#AFC: Cleveland Browns 20, New England Patriots 13|beating the New England Patriots on January 1, 1995]], and have lost nine or more games each season since 2008.
On November 30, 2015, the Browns played the Baltimore Ravens in their first ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' game in six years. After trailing 17–3 in the second quarter, the Browns rallied behind quarterbacks [[Josh McCown]] and [[Austin Davis]] to tie the game at 27 with 1:47 left. Then Browns cornerback [[Tramon Williams]] intercepted a pass at mid-field with 50 seconds left. Cleveland attempted a 51-yard field goal with 3 seconds left to win the game, only to see the attempt blocked and returned by Ravens safety [[Will Hill]] for a touchdown, handing the Browns their most painful loss in recent history.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2015113000/2015/REG12/ravens@browns#menu=gameinfo%7CcontentId%3A0ap3000000592057&tab=recap&recap=fullstory | title=Ravens win as time expires on blocked field goal return | agency=Associated Press | date=November 30, 2015 | publisher=nfl.com | accessdate=October 11, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Draper | first=Kevin | title=Ravens Return Blocked Field Goal For TD With No Time Left To Beat Browns | url=http://deadspin.com/ravens-return-blocked-field-goal-for-td-with-no-time-le-1745412582 | publisher=[[Deadspin]] | date=November 30, 2015 | accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref> The event was called "The Block" by some disgruntled fans on Twitter only moments after the end of the game.<ref>{{cite news | last=Draper | first=Kevin | title=Browns Fans Shot The Saddest Goddamn Videos As Their Team Blew It Once Again | url=http://deadspin.com/browns-fans-shot-the-saddest-goddamn-videos-as-their-te-1745415079 | publisher=Deadspin | date=December 1, 2015 | accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref>
The Browns arguably hit rock-bottom in the [[2017 Cleveland Browns season|2017 season]], where, under head coach [[Hue Jackson]], the Browns went a league-worst and franchise record-worst 0-16, becoming just the second team in NFL history since the implementation of the 16-game season (after the [[2008 Detroit Lions season|2008 Detroit Lions]]) to [[List of winless seasons|lose every game in a season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000900572/article/cleveland-browns-finish-2017-season-016|title=Cleveland Browns finish 2017 season 0-16|website=NFL.com|accessdate=5 January 2018}}</ref>
==Cleveland Cavaliers== {{Further2|[[The Shot]]|[[The Decision (TV special)|The Decision]]|[[The Block (basketball)|The Block]]}}
The [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] are a professional basketball team who have played in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA) since [[1970–71 Cleveland Cavaliers season|1970]].
Over the franchise's first 16 years, the team produced just three winning seasons, the highlight being the [[1975–76 Cleveland Cavaliers season|1975–76]] "Miracle at Richfield" team, whose improbable playoff run was doomed by an injury to [[Jim Chones]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/cavs/index.ssf/2012/11/cleveland_cavaliers_have_seen.html|title=Cleveland Cavaliers have seen their share of season-crippling injuries: NBA Insider|last=Schmitt Boyer|first=Mary|date=24 November 2012|publisher=The Plain Dealer|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref> The early-mid 1980s saw the franchise ruined by owner [[Ted Stepien]]'s decision to trade away every first-round pick the Cavaliers held for inferior talent, while those picks turned into players such as [[James Worthy]] and [[Derek Harper]]. Despite this, the Cavaliers gained respectability towards the end of the decade and the early 1990s, making the playoffs with players such as [[Mark Price]], [[Brad Daugherty (basketball)|Brad Daugherty]], [[Hot Rod Williams]] and Craig Ehlo on their roster.
In 1989, the Cavaliers faced the [[1988–89 Chicago Bulls season|Chicago Bulls]] in the first round of the [[1989 NBA Playoffs|playoffs]]. In the decisive fifth game, [[Craig Ehlo]] had given the Cavs the lead with three seconds to play. However, the Bulls' [[Michael Jordan]] jumped over Ehlo to make the game-winning shot, and the Bulls won the game, 101–100, to clinch the series.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jordan Hits "The Shot"|url=http://www.nba.com/history/jordancav_moments.html|publisher=National Basketball Association|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Hyduk | first=John | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/14/sports/cleveland-sports-disappointing-fans-since-1964.html?_r=0 | title=Cleveland: Disappointing Fans Since '64 | work=The New York Times | date=May 13, 2013 | accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> Despite six trips to the playoffs between 1988 and 1994, including a [[1992 NBA Playoffs|1992 Eastern Conference Finals]] appearance, the Cavaliers never made it to the NBA Finals, as Jordan's Bulls defeated them in the playoffs five times during the [[Brad Daugherty (basketball)|Daugherty]]–[[Larry Nance|Nance]]–[[Mark Price|Price]] era.<ref>{{cite news | last=Swartz | first=Greg | title=Cleveland Cavaliers Can Learn from Franchise's Only Other Big Three | url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2200748-cleveland-cavaliers-can-learn-from-franchises-only-other-big-three | work=Bleacher Report | date=September 17, 2014 | accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
In 2007, Ohio native [[LeBron James]] led the Cavaliers to their first [[2007 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] appearance. However, they were swept by the [[2006–07 San Antonio Spurs season|San Antonio Spurs]]. Two years later, the Cavs, despite posting a conference-best 66–16 record, lost the [[2009 NBA Playoffs#Conference Finals: (1) Cleveland Cavaliers vs. (3) Orlando Magic|2009 Eastern Conference Finals]] to the [[2008–09 Orlando Magic season|Orlando Magic]], 4–2.<ref name=brcurse/> In the following season's playoffs, though his team always possessed home-court advantage, the reigning two-time MVP James and the [[2009–10 Cleveland Cavaliers season|2009–10 Cavaliers]] (61–21) were defeated by the visiting [[2009–10 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]] in Game 5 of the [[2010 NBA Playoffs#(1) Cleveland Cavaliers vs. (4) Boston Celtics|Eastern Conference Semifinals]], 120–88. The Cavaliers went on to lose the series, 4–2.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=300513002 | title=LeBron's triple-double not enough as Celtics move on to face Magic | date=June 14, 2010 | publisher=ESPN | accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref>
During the 2010 NBA free agency period, James was featured in a television special titled ''[[The Decision (TV special)|The Decision]]''. Having notified the Cavaliers just moments prior to the television event, James announced "In this fall — this is very tough — in this fall I'm gonna take my talents to South Beach and join the [[Miami Heat]]." The quote was heavily criticized.<ref>{{cite web | last=D'Angelo | first=Tom | url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/sports/basketball/the-king-of-south-beach-lebron-james-will-sign-wit/nL8Lk/ | title=The King of South Beach: LeBron James will sign with Miami Heat | work=The Palm Beach Post | date=July 9, 2010 | accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Kerasotis | first=Peter | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/25/sports/basketball/for-miami-heat-high-hopes-but-lower-volume.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all | title=For Miami Heat, High Hopes but Lower Volume | work=The New York Times | date=December 24, 2011 | accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> James, along with the help of [[Dwyane Wade]] and [[Chris Bosh]], led the Heat to four consecutive NBA Finals appearances, winning twice, while the Cavaliers' record fell to the bottom of the NBA echelon.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gaines|first=Cork|url= http://www.businessinsider.com/the-cavaliers-capitalized-off-of-lebron-for-an-entire-year-after-he-left-but-are-now-feeling-the-sting-2012-2|title=The Cavaliers Capitalized Off Of LeBron For An Entire Year After He Left, But Are Now Feeling The Sting|publisher=''Business Insider''|date=February 14, 2012|accessdate=June 6, 2015}}</ref> In those four years without LeBron, they acquired three number-one picks ([[Kyrie Irving]] in 2011, [[Anthony Bennett (basketball)|Anthony Bennett]] in 2013 and [[Andrew Wiggins]] in 2014). The team struggled to win games, setting an NBA record for most consecutive losses with 26 in the [[2010–11 Cleveland Cavaliers season|2010–11 season]].
After the 2013–14 season, James opted out of his contract with Miami and returned to the Cavaliers.<ref>{{cite web | last=Broussard | first=Chris | url=http://espn.go.com/nba/truehoop/miamiheat/story/_/id/11127329/lebron-james-opt-contract-miami-heat | title=Agent to Heat: LeBron opting out | publisher=ESPN | date=June 25, 2014 | accessdate=June 16, 2015}}</ref> After signing James, the Cavaliers traded their two most recent number-one draft picks, Andrew Wiggins and Anthony Bennett, for Minnesota Timberwolves star [[Kevin Love]] to form their own "Big 3," which was rounded out by Irving. The Cavs advanced to the [[2015 NBA Finals]]. However, several Cavaliers players were injured during the season, including [[Anderson Varejão]] with a ruptured Achilles tendon, Love with a dislocated shoulder, and Irving with a fractured patella in Game 1 of the Finals.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cleveland.com/cavs/index.ssf/2015/06/kyrie_irving_injury_nba_finals.html | title=Kyrie Irving fractured his left kneecap and will miss remainder of playoffs | last=Haynes | first=Chris | date=5 June 2015 | publisher=Northeast Ohio Media Group | accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref> Though losing nearly all of James' supporting cast, the Cavaliers took a 2–1 series lead before falling to the [[2014–15 Golden State Warriors season|Golden State Warriors]], 4–2.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/eye-on-basketball/25197829/nba-finals-schedule-golden-state-warriors-vs-cleveland-cavaliers | title=2015 NBA Finals: Warriors win NBA title by beating Cavs 4–2 in NBA Finals | last=Moore | first=Matt | date=June 5, 2015 | publisher=CBS Sports | accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref>
The next season, despite a 30–11 start, the team fired coach [[David Blatt]] and replaced him with assistant [[Tyronn Lue]].<ref>{{cite news|last=McMenamin|first=Dave|title=Cavs GM: 'Not fair' to say team taking directives from LeBron James|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/14629410/cleveland-cavaliers-gm-david-griffin-says-lebron-james-run-organization|publisher=ESPN|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref> It was revealed that Blatt had a turbulent relationship with James as well as several other players. The Cavaliers lost to the [[Chicago Bulls]] 96–83 at home in Lue's debut as Cavaliers' head coach.
The Cavs finished the season 57–25, earning the top seed in the Eastern Conference. They advanced to the NBA Finals, losing only two games on the way.
The Cavaliers defeated the [[2015–16 Golden State Warriors season|Golden State Warriors]] in the [[2016 NBA Finals]] which was a rematch of the previous season's Finals.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Brian|title=NBA Finals rematch set as Warriors, Cavs to meet again|url=http://www.nba.com/2016/news/05/31/nba-finals-lookahead.ap/|agency=''Associated Press''|publisher=National Basketball Association|date=May 31, 2016|accessdate=June 2, 2016}}</ref> Through the first four games, the Cavs were trailing the record-setting 73-win Warriors in the series, 3–1. However, the Cavaliers won the next three games to win their first NBA championship in franchise history, becoming the first team in NBA Finals history to overcome a 3–1 deficit, and the first team since 1978 to win a Finals Game 7 on the road. A particularly memorable moment in Game 7 was when James successfully pursued and blocked [[Andre Iguodala]] on a fast break late in the fourth quarter, a defensive play known among Cavs fans as [[The Block (basketball)|The Block]]. Following would be a three-point shot by [[Kyrie Irving]], to put the Cavaliers ahead for good at 92–89 with 53 seconds left in the fourth quarter. Following that, Cavaliers' forward Kevin Love was switched and forced to play one-on-one defense against [[Stephen Curry]]. Curry tried an array of dribbling moves but ultimately missed his 3-point attempt, with the typically slow-footed Love staying in front of and pestering the Warriors guard.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McMenamin|first1=Dave|last2=Windhorst|first2=Brian|title=Champion Cavs drink it all in after lifting Cleveland's title drought|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/playoffs/2016/story/_/id/16362353/nba-finals-2016-lebron-james-cleveland-cavaliers-bask-nba-title-glory|publisher=ESPN|date=June 20, 2016|accessdate=July 3, 2016}}</ref> This game is being called "The Comeback" and "The End" as this win ended Northeast Ohio's 52-year championship drought.<ref>{{cite news|last=Withers|first=Tom|title=The End: Cleveland rocks as title drought ends in NBA Finals|url=http://www.nba.com/2016/news/06/19/cleveland-ends-drought.ap/index.html?ls=iref:nbahpts|agency=Associated Press|publisher=National Basketball Association|date=June 19, 2016|accessdate=June 20, 2016}}</ref>
==Cleveland Indians== {{Further2|[[The Catch (baseball)|The Catch]]|[[Curse of Rocky Colavito]]|[[1997 World Series#Game 7|1997 World Series Game 7]]|[[Cleveland Indians name and logo controversy]]}}
The [[Cleveland Indians]], like the Browns and Cavaliers, also experienced the curse. The Indians' failure to win a [[World Series]] since {{wsy|1948}} has led the ''[[Cleveland Scene]]'' to dub the team's shortcomings '''The Curse of Chief Wahoo'''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pattakos|first=Peter|url=http://www.clevescene.com/gyrobase/the-curse-of-chief-wahoo/Content?oid=2954423&showFullText=true|title=The Curse of Chief Wahoo |publisher=''The Cleveland Scene''|date=April 25, 2012|accessdate=March 2, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120062629/http://www.clevescene.com/gyrobase/the-curse-of-chief-wahoo/Content?oid=2954423&showFullText=true|archivedate=January 20, 2013}}</ref> [[Chief Wahoo]] is a Native American caricature which serves as the Indians' cap insignia. The Chief Wahoo insignia has been [[Cleveland Indians name and logo controversy|controversial]]. The Indians considered changing it in 1993,<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheeran|first=Thomas J.|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/298090/INDIANS-WILL-KEEP-LOGO-DESPITE-OBJECTIONS.html?pg=all|title=Indians Will Keep Logo, Despite Objections|publisher=''Desert News''|date=July 2, 1993|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> but the logo was retained on the home caps, alternate away caps, and jersey sleeves until 2019. In 2002, the Indians introduced a script "I" alternate logo and cap insignia. In 2011, the alternate logo was changed to the block "C". The [[Curse of Rocky Colavito]] is another phenomenon that is supposedly preventing the Indians from winning a World Series.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pluto|first=Terry|url=http://www.cleveland.com/pluto/blog/index.ssf/2010/04/50_years_later_colavito_trade.html|title=50 years later, the Cleveland Indians' trade of Rocky Colavito still stinks: Terry Pluto|publisher=''The Cleveland Plain Dealer''|date=April 16, 2010|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> The 1989 film ''[[Major League (film)|Major League]]'' was based on the Indians' poor performance since 1954, as the Indians had finished within five games of a playoff berth just three times between 1955 and 1989.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/sports_blog/2010/07/sports-legend-revealed-the-movie-major-league-originally-had-a-twist-ending.html | title = Sports Legend Revealed: The movie 'Major League' originally had a twist ending | first = Brian | last = Cronin | date = July 20, 2010 | accessdate = June 20, 2016 | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] }}</ref>
In [[1954 Cleveland Indians season|1954]], the Indians had one of the greatest seasons in baseball history, winning 111 games in what was the only time from 1949–1958 in which the [[New York Yankees]] did not win the American League pennant. Heavily favored against the [[History of the New York Giants (baseball)|New York Giants]] in the World Series, the Indians seemed poised to break the game open in the top of the eighth inning, when Indians first baseman [[Vic Wertz]] hit a deep fly ball to center field. However, since the game was held at the [[Polo Grounds]] (which was 483 feet from home plate to center field), the ball was not a home run, although the ball would have been a home run in any other ballpark. As such, Giants center fielder [[Willie Mays]] made an improbable, over-the-shoulder, no-look catch on the run to rob Wertz of an extra-base hit, leaving the game tied at two in what became known as [[The Catch (baseball)|The Catch]]. In the bottom of the tenth inning, Giants batter [[Dusty Rhodes (outfielder)|Dusty Rhodes]] hit a walk-off home run to give the Giants the win. The Giants went on to sweep the Indians in the World Series in what became one of the biggest upsets in World Series history. In 1969, the when Major League Baseball expanded its postseason and introduced divisional play, the Indians were placed in the [[American League East]]. Despite the introductions of divisions and expanded playoffs, the Indians found themselves unable to win the AL East division, as they finished above .500 on just four occasions during their time in the AL East from 1969–1993. The Indians did not return to the postseason until the postseason was expanded further in 1995.
The historic [[1995 Cleveland Indians season|1995]] season saw the Indians win 100 games and make it to the [[1995 World Series|World Series]] for the first time in 41 years. However, they lost in six games to the [[1995 Atlanta Braves season|Atlanta Braves]], led by the Braves' [[Big Three (Atlanta Braves)|Big Three]] of [[Greg Maddux]], [[John Smoltz]], and World Series MVP [[Tom Glavine]]. The Braves' victory was their only World Series win in their fifteen consecutive trips to the playoffs between 1991 and 2005. In [[1996 Cleveland Indians season|1996]], the Indians won 99 games, which was the most in the American League. However, they lost the [[1996 American League Division Series|ALDS]] in four games to the [[1996 Baltimore Orioles season|Orioles]]. The Indians returned to the [[1997 World Series|World Series]] in 1997 and were leading 2–1 heading into the bottom of the ninth inning of Game 7, only for [[José Mesa]] to blow the save to [[Craig Counsell]]'s sacrifice fly, allowing the [[1997 Florida Marlins season|Marlins]] to tie the game in the ninth and win in the eleventh on a walk-off single by [[Edgar Renteria]] that deflected off the glove of Indians pitcher [[Charles Nagy]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Miles|first=Scott|title=Open Mic: 11 Years Later, Indians' World Series Loss to Marlins Still Hurts|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/28986-open-mic-11-years-later-indians-world-series-loss-to-marlins-still-hurts|publisher=''Bleacher Report''|date=June 11, 2008|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Blocks|first=Starting|url=http://www.cleveland.com/ohio-sports-blog/index.ssf/2011/10/cleveland_indians_world_series.html|title=Cleveland Indians World Series teams: Won it in 1920 and 1948; lost it in 1954, 1995 and 1997|publisher=''Cleveland''|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=March 2, 2014}}</ref> The Indians failed to return to the World Series in [[1998 Cleveland Indians season|1998]], losing the [[1998 American League Championship Series|ALCS]] in six games. In [[1999 Cleveland Indians season|1999]], the Indians went up 2–0 against the [[1999 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]], only to lose the next three games of the series by a combined score of 44–18.
After winning division titles six times in seven seasons from 1995 to 2001, the Indians only appeared in the postseason twice in 14 years under the often frugal Dolan family ownership ([[Larry Dolan]] bought the team in 2000). In the [[2007 American League Championship Series]], the Indians were up 3–1 and one win away from advancing to the World Series, but they lost the last three games to the [[2007 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]] by a combined score of 30–5, denying the team a World Series berth.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/22/sports/baseball/22alcs.html | title=Red Sox' Comeback Lands Them in World Series | last=Curry | first=Jack | date=October 22, 2007 | work=The New York Times | accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> In 2013, the Indians won their final ten games of the season to make the playoffs again, but lost [[2013 American League Wild Card Game|the play-in Wild Card game]] at home to the [[2013 Tampa Bay Rays season|Tampa Bay Rays]] by a score of 4–0.<ref>{{cite news | last=Kepner | first=Tyler | title=Still Playing on Road, the Rays Send Another Team Home for Good | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/03/sports/baseball/rays-beat-indians-to-win-national-league-wild-card.html?ref=sports&_r=0 | work=The New York Times | date=October 2, 2013 | accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref>
Despite the Cavaliers 2016 NBA title, the Indians continued to come up short in the playoffs. Later that same year, The Indians advanced to the [[2016 World Series|World Series]], giving Cleveland a chance to become the first city since [[Los Angeles]] in 1988 to have both NBA and MLB championships in the same year. The Indians held a 3–1 lead against the [[2016 Chicago Cubs season|Chicago Cubs]], but Chicago rallied to win the last three games and break [[Curse of the Billy Goat|their own curse]]; as a result, the Indians currently hold the longest active championship drought in baseball. In 2017, the Indians returned to the playoffs as a heavy favorite to return to the World Series. They won 102 games, highlighted by an American League record 22-game winning streak. However, the Indians lost the [[2017 American League Division Series|Division Series]] to the [[New York Yankees]], 3–2. The Indians returned to the postseason in [[2018 Cleveland Indians season|2018]], but were swept in the [[2018 American League Division Series|Division Series]] by the [[2018 Houston Astros season|Houston Astros]].
==Other sports== The Cleveland sports curse has generally centered around its major teams.<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.gq.com/gallery/worst-sports-franchises-teams-of-all-time| title = The 20 Worst Sports Franchises of All Time | first = Rob | last = Tannenbaum | work = [[GQ (magazine)|GQ]] | date = October 2013 | accessdate = June 19, 2016 }}</ref> However, other teams based in Cleveland won championships during the city's major title drought, and one [[Greater Cleveland]] native won a world championship individually.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.cleveland.com/tipoff/index.ssf/2013/09/cleveland_browns_indians_and_c.html| title = Cleveland Browns, Indians and Cavs combined are worst sports franchises in history, says a magazine no one around here reads | first = Michael | last = McIntyre | date = September 26, 2013 | accessdate = June 19, 2016 | work = [[The Plain Dealer]] }}</ref>
<!-- Choreographed and scripted outcomes, such as the Miz's WWE championship, are not to be included on this page. --> ===Cleveland Crunch=== The [[Cleveland Crunch]], a [[:Category:Defunct indoor soccer clubs in the United States|defunct]] [[indoor soccer]] club, won three championships in the [[National Professional Soccer League (1984–2001)|National Professional Soccer League]] (NPSL) during the 1990s. The Crunch beat the [[St. Louis Ambush (1992–2000)|St. Louis Ambush]] three games to one in a best-of-five championship series, clinching the team's first title in a double [[Overtime (sports)|overtime]] Game 4 win at the [[Wolstein Center|CSU Convocation Center]] on April 27, 1994. The team went on to win two more titles, in 1996 and 1999, before the league itself disbanded in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|author=Keh, Andrew|date=June 7, 2015|title=Cleveland, City of Champions (at Least in Indoor Soccer of the '90s)|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2015/06/08/sports/soccer/though-cleveland-thinks-its-starving-for-a-championship-it-feasted-in-the-90s.html?_r=0&referer=https://www.google.com/|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|accessdate=July 10, 2016}}</ref>
===Lake Erie Monsters=== On June 11, 2016, the [[Cleveland Monsters|Lake Erie Monsters]] of the [[American Hockey League]] won the [[Calder Cup]], defeating the [[Hershey Bears]] at [[Quicken Loans Arena]] to win the series 4–0.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lake Erie Monsters Bring A Championship To Cleveland |url=http://www.jacketscannon.com/2016/6/11/11910714/lake-erie-monsters-brings-a-championship-to-cleveland |author=Little, Jack |work=The Cannon |date=June 11, 2016 |accessdate=June 21, 2016}}</ref> The team, also owned by [[Dan Gilbert (businessman)|Dan Gilbert]], shares its arena with the Cavaliers, who won the NBA title eight days later.
It was the tenth overall Calder Cup won by a Cleveland team. The original [[Cleveland Barons (1937–73)|Cleveland Barons]] that played from 1937 to 1973 won nine Calder Cups, with the last in 1964, coincidentally the last time one of the major sports franchises in the city won a championship prior to the 2016 Cavaliers.
===Stipe Miocic=== On May 14, 2016, mixed martial artist [[Stipe Miocic]], a native of [[Euclid, Ohio]], a Cleveland suburb, won the [[UFC Heavyweight Championship]] at [[UFC 198]] in [[Curitiba, Brazil]], knocking out Brazil's [[Fabricio Werdum]]. Three hours prior, [[ESPN]] had aired a ''[[30 for 30]]'' episode called "Believeland," documenting Cleveland's major-league title drought. The Indians and Cavaliers Twitter accounts congratulated him shortly afterwards.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kalland|first=Robby|title=Cleveland finally wins a title: Stipe Miocic takes UFC heavyweight title|url=http://www.cbssports.com/general/news/cleveland-finally-has-a-world-champion-stipe-miocic-wins-ufc-heavyweight-title/|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=May 15, 2016|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref> They and the Browns had earlier wished him luck.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Damon|title=Cleveland sports teams throw support behind Stipe Miocic at UFC 198|url=http://www.foxsports.com/ufc/story/ufc-stipe-miocic-cleveland-cavs-browns-indians-throw-support-ufc-198-051416|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=May 14, 2016|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref> He tweeted encouragement to the Cavaliers, who hoped to keep the winning streak alive in the [[2016 NBA Playoffs]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Damon|title=Stipe Miocic sends message to Cleveland Cavs following championship win|url=http://www.foxsports.com/ufc/story/ufc-198-stipe-miocic-cleveland-cavaliers-cavs-sends-message-following-championship-win-051516|publisher=Fox Sports|date=May 15, 2016|accessdate=May 30, 2016}}</ref> Some media outlets characterized Miocic's title as having ended Cleveland's 52-year championship drought, as well as Miocic himself in the post-fight interview.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kyte|first=E. {{North American Slave Revolts}} The '''''Creole'' case''' was the result of an American slave revolt in November 1841 on board the ''Creole'', a ship involved in the [[United States]] [[coastwise slave trade]]. As 128 slaves gained freedom after the Africans ordered the ship sailed to [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], it has been termed the "most successful [[slave revolt]] in US history".{{cite news | title = Brig Creole slaves | first = Michael Paul | last = Williams | url = http://www.timesdispatch.com/special-section/black-history/brig-creole-slaves/article_11391522-9222-5006-95eb-c1db7f61f9b4.html | newspaper = [[Richmond Times-Dispatch]] | location = Richmond, VA | date = 11 February 2002 | accessdate = February 2, 2010 }} Two persons died as a result of the revolt, a black slave and a white slave trader. The United Kingdom had abolished the slave trade for British vessels in 1807, and slavery in its colonies effective 1834; its officials in the Bahamas ruled that most of the slaves on the ''Creole'' were freed after arrival there, if they chose to stay. Officials detained the 19 men who rebelled on ship until the Admiralty Court of Nassau held a special session in April 1842 to consider charges of piracy against them. The Court ruled that the men had been illegally held in slavery and had the right to use force to gain freedom; they were not seeking private gain. The 17 survivors (two had died in the interim), were released to freedom. When the ''Creole'' reached New Orleans in December 1841 with three women and two child slaves aboard (who had made the mistake of remaining in hiding), Southerners were outraged about the loss of property. Relations between the United States and Britain were strained for a time. The incident occurred during negotiations for the [[Webster-Ashburton Treaty]] of 1842 but was not directly addressed. The parties settled on seven crimes qualifying for extradition in the treaty; they did not include slave revolts. Eventually claims for losses of slaves from ''Creole'' and two other US ships were covered, along with other claims dating to 1814, in a treaty of 1853 between the US and Britain, for which an arbitration commission awarded settlements in 1855 against each nation. ==The revolt== In the fall of 1841, the [[brig]] ''Creole,'' owned by Johnson and Eperson of [[Richmond, Virginia]], was transporting 135 slaves for sale in [[New Orleans]], the South's major market. It had left Richmond with 103 slaves and picked up another 32 at [[Hampton Roads, Virginia]]. Most were owned by Johnson and Eperson, and 26 were owned by Thomas McCargo, a slave trader who was one of the passengers on board. While the United States had prohibited the international slave trade effective in 1808, it permitted the domestic slave trade among those states that authorized slavery; many slave traders transported captives by the [[coastwise slave trade]] along the East Coast. The brig also carried tobacco, a crew of 10, the captain's wife, daughter and niece; four passengers, including slave traders; and eight black slave servants, for a total of 160 on board.[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2717095?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2134&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=56236344963 Jervey, Edward D. and Huber, C. Harold. "The ''Creole'' Affair"], ''The Journal of Negro History'', Vol. 65, No. 3 (Summer 1980), pp. 196–211, accessed 8 April 2013 [[Madison Washington]], a refugee slave who had been recaptured after returning from Canada to Virginia for his wife, was among those being shipped for sale in New Orleans.R. Edward Lee, "Madison Washington, Slave Mutineer," ''Blacfax,'' Winter/Spring 1998, Vol. 8 Issue 36, p. 8 The slaves were kept in the forward hold, and he gained the deck after one of the crew had lifted the grate. On November 7, 1841, Washington and eighteen other male slaves rebelled; they overwhelmed the crew and killed John R. Hewell, one of the [[slave trader]]s, with a knife. The crew and passengers had only one gun among them, which they never used. The captain, who was wounded, and two mates had gone up into the rigging to escape the fighting. One of the slaves was badly wounded and later died. Some others of the crew were wounded but all survived. The slaves took overseer William Merritt at his word that he would navigate for them. They first demanded that the ship be taken to [[Liberia]], which the US had established as a free colony in West Africa. Merritt said that voyage was impossible as they did not have enough food or water. Another slave leader, Ben Blacksmith, said they should be taken to the British West Indies, as he knew the slaves from the ''[[Hermosa (slave ship)|Hermosa]]'' had gained freedom there the previous year. ==British actions in Nassau== On November 9, 1841, the ''Creole'' reached [[Nassau, Bahamas|Nassau]], where it was first boarded by the [[Maritime pilot|harbor pilot]] and his crew, all local black Bahamians.''The Times'', January 21, 1842, p. 3 They told the American slaves that, under Bahamian colonial law, they were free. The crew advised them to go ashore at once. The Quarantine Officer came aboard. As the captain Robert Ensor was badly wounded, the officer took First Mate Zephaniah Gifford to inform the American Consul of the events. At the Consul's request, the [[Francis Cockburn|governor]] of the Bahamas ordered a guard to board the ''Creole'' to prevent the escape of the men implicated in Hewell's death. The 24 black soldiers were led by a white officer. This action prevented the slaves from dispersing into the city. Fearing the British would apply their ban on slavery to the American slaves, the American consul tried to organize American sailors on the island to take back control of the ship. He intended to have them sail the ship out of British jurisdiction with the slaves still aboard. An American group of sailors approached the ship on November 12, intending to sail it away, but were foiled by a Bahamian who shouted a warning to the officer of the guard aboard the ''Creole.'' He threatened to fire into the Americans in their boat, and they withdrew. After an investigation by magistrates, on Friday, 13 November 1841, the Bahamian Attorney-General went aboard. He told the nineteen rebels that they would be detained. He informed the remainder: "You are free, and at liberty to go onshore, and wherever you please." A fleet of small boats manned by locals, who until then had surrounded the brig at a distance, immediately came forward. The Attorney-General warned the people against boarding the ''Creole,'' but said they could provide passage to those slaves who wished to go to shore. Most did so, although three women, a girl, and a boy stayed in hiding on board. They eventually sailed with the ship to New Orleans and back to slavery. The New Providence government arranged for a ship bound for [[Jamaica]], also under British control, to take passengers to that island for free, and announced it in the newspaper. Numerous American blacks from the ''Creole'' left for Jamaica aboard it. After the Bahamian government arrested the conspirators, the United States government dropped its claims for all the slaves to be returned to its custody. {{citation needed|date=August 2011}} There was no extradition treaty at the time between Britain and the United States governing such circumstances. The British authorities determined that the slaves had not committed any breach of British or maritime law. As under British law they were free men, they were considered to have the right to use force to escape the detention of illegal slavery.''The Times'', February 16, 1842, p. 13: Quote: "In answer to an inquiry of Lord BROUGHAM, Lord ABERDEEN stated that orders had been sent out to the Governor of the Bahamas to liberate the 19 slaves now under constraint at Nassau for the mutiny and murder on board that vessel, unless (which is not to be apprehended) there were any local laws which justified or demanded a contrary course." The Admiralty Court in Nassau held a special session in April to consider a charge of [[piracy]] against the men implicated in the mutiny. Ruling that their action was not piracy, the Court ordered the surviving 17 mutineers to be released on April 16, 1842.''The Times'', May 18, 1842, p. 3 As a total of 128 slaves gained their freedom, this has been described as the "most successful slave revolt in US history". The ''Creole'' had departed months before for the United States, reaching its original destination of New Orleans on December 2, 1841. Five slaves were still aboard, outraging planters and politicians who learned that the remaining slaves had been freed by British authorities. The case attracted national attention in the United States and provoked diplomatic controversy. In Boston in 1842, abolitionist [[William E. Channing]] published a pamphlet, "The Duty of the Free States or Remarks Suggested by the Case of the 'Creole'," to refute claims by Southern politicians that the human property of U.S. slave owners should be protected in foreign ports.[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/ammem/aaohtml/exhibit/aopart1b.html "Slaves Commandeer the Creole", Slavery: Flights to Freedom], ''African-American Odyssey'': February 5 through May 2, 1998; Library of Congress, accessed <14 February 2014 The issue was also under discussion due to negotiations over the Webster-Ashburton Treaty, which was ratified with the United Kingdom that year. Less than a year later, the ''Creole'' was wrecked in a violent storm while in harbour at [[Funchal]], [[Madeira]].''The Times'', November 22, 1842, p. 4 ==Political consequences== The ''Creole'' case generated diplomatic tension between the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] and the [[United States]], and political rumblings within the United States. Southerners were outraged to have lost property in another instance of British colonists freeing slaves from American ships that had gone into their ports in the Caribbean. The [[John Tyler]] administration supported Southerners in seeking the return of the slaves. Although known as an [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], [[Daniel Webster]] as [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] served John Tyler; he stated the US position to the United Kingdom that the slaves were legal property of US citizens and demanded their return. The United Kingdom had abolished slavery effective August 1834, and it rejected the U.S. claim. It had advised all nations that under its law, ships that went into its colonial ports would forfeit any slaves on board. It said that Nassau was a British territory where British law must be applied. Under it, the 'slaves' aboard the ''Creole'' were to be considered free passengers. Accordingly, unless they could be proved to have broken local or maritime law, it would be false imprisonment to detain them against their will. The abolitionist [[Charles Sumner]] argued that the slaves "became free men when taken, by the voluntary action of their owners, beyond the jurisdiction of the slave states." In March 1842 US Representative [[Joshua Reed Giddings]] of [[Ohio]] introduced a series of nine resolutions on this topic, arguing against the federal government acting on behalf of the slaveholders. He argued that Virginia state law did not apply to slaves who were outside Virginian waters, the federal government had no part in it, and the [[coastwise slave trade]] was unconstitutional, as slaves were beyond state law on the high seas, and thus free. Southerners in the House of Representatives disagreed with his position. The members censured Giddings by a large margin for violating an informal [[gag rule]] that had been in effect since 1836, barring discussion of slavery in the House. He promptly resigned. When the Ohio legislature held a special election in May 1842 for his seat, the voters of Ohio overwhelmingly reelected Giddings,[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0312/74305.html Andrew Glass, "Ohio Whig Joshua Giddings resigns, March 22, 1842"], Politico.com, 22 March 2012, accessed 31 March 2013 by 7,469 to 383.[https://books.google.com/books?id=XTLFKrmJPgcC&dq=%22children+of+the+enterprise%22+musson&source=gbs_navlinks_s Gerald Horne, ''Negro Comrades of the Crown: African Americans and the British Empire Fight the U.S. Before Emancipation''], New York University (NYU) Press, 2012, p. 137 Encouraged by the outcome of the ''Creole'' revolt, abolitionists renewed their political attacks on slavery and the coastwise trade. In the newspaper article, "The Hero Mutineers," Madison Washington was named the '[[romantic hero]].'"The Hero Mutineers," ''The New York Evangelist'', 1842 Washington was said to have shown sympathy toward the white crew members on the ''Creole'' by preventing his fellow slave mates from murdering all of them when they made a last effort to regain control. He was said to have personally dressed sailors' wounds after the revolt. The case roused strong feelings on both sides of the Atlantic, as the events occurred during the negotiations related to the [[Webster-Ashburton Treaty]] of 1842 between the two nations, primarily to settle the borders between the US and Canada, a British colony. According to the ''New York Courier and Inquirer'', Daniel Webster, as Secretary of State, wrote to [[Alexander Baring, 1st Baron Ashburton|Lord Ashburton]], then in Washington, DC:
The Creole case is presented in strong terms by Mr Webster in a letter (which, when published, will bring all the anti-slavery people about his ears)..." To this Lord Ashburton replied that as the case had effectively arisen after his departure from England he was 'not empowered to treat upon the subject'. He reaffirmed the position that as slavery was no longer recognized under British law, any foreign slave arriving in British possessions was automatically considered as free — as was also the case in those American states that did not recognize slavery. He did however promise that British officials in the West Indies would be given 'directions'...'to do nothing in this respect when it can be properly avoided' in the interests of 'good neighbourhood'.''The Times'', 15 September 1842, p. 5The correspondence between Webster and Ashburton was published in ''The Works of Daniel Webster'' (1853), vol. VI: [https://archive.org/stream/worksdanweb06websrich#page/272/mode/2up/search/ashburton]
Among other declarations, the Webster-Ashburton Treaty called for a final end to the slave trade on the high seas, to be enforced by both signatories. Seven lawsuits were lodged against insurance companies in Louisiana by slave owners who had suffered financial losses due to the revolt, as the insurance companies initially refused to compensate them.[http://nutrias.org/~nopl/inv/creole.htm "Louisiana. Commercial Court (Orleans Parish). Suits relating to the slave mutiny aboard the brig Creole, 1841 [Docket Nos. 4408, 4409, 4410, 4411, 4413, 4414, 4419"]], New Orleans Public Library: City Archives Most of these insurance cases were consolidated and eventually heard by the Louisiana State Supreme Court.Result? ==Earlier cases== The ''Comet'' in 1830 and the ''Encomium'' in 1833 were American ships in the [[coastwise slave trade]] that were forced by weather into British Caribbean ports while carrying numerous slaves bound for the domestic market in New Orleans. The British treated the slaves on board as aliens, and freed both groups. Britain eventually paid compensation for these seizures, as it had not yet abolished slavery in its territories.[https://books.google.com/books?id=jwQ4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA79&lpg=PA79&dq=ships+Comet+and+Encomium&source=bl&ots=Syf0iHEFjY&sig=GWIXztuBAA3xY2EfBrBuMPbX8Ac&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8khjUfeKCMuMyAHytoHQCA&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=ships%20Comet%20and%20Encomium&f=false Lord McNair, "5: Slavery and the Slave Trade", ''International Law Opinions''], Cambridge University Press, 1956, p. 79 When Parliament abolished slavery in its territories in 1833, Britain advised other countries that slave ships that put into its ports would forfeit the slaves without compensation. After British abolition of slavery in its colonies, effective in 1834, its officials freed slaves from the ''[[Enterprise (slave ship)|Enterprise]]'' (1835), and the ''Hermosa'' (1840), without compensation. In 1840, the ''[[Hermosa (slave ship)|Hermosa]]'', a US schooner in the coastwise slave trade carrying 38 slaves from Richmond to New Orleans for sale, went aground on one of the Abacos islands in the Bahamas. After wreckers took the ship to port, the captain refused to let the slaves off and with the US [[consul (representative)|consul]], tried to arrange for another ship to take and deliver his slave cargo to the United States. British magistrates backed with armed force went onto the ''Hermosa'', taking the slaves off and freeing them when they reached the port. The Americans protested. The ''Enterprise'' and ''Hermosa'' cases were submitted for arbitration under an 1853 claims treaty and, together with claims for the ''Creole'' and a variety of other unrelated claims dating to 1814, Britain paid a settlement in 1855 to the United States for these three cases. A total of nearly 450 American slaves achieved freedom due to British colonies' actions in these five cases. ==Compensation== After years of discussion, the United Kingdom and the United States signed a February 1853 Treaty of Claims which articles included the claims of slave-owners who had suffered financially[https://books.google.com/books?id=GrERAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA226&lpg ''Niles Weekly Register''], 10 June 1837, p. 226: Note: Slave trader Oliver Simpson, of the District of Columbia, brought suit against the Charleston Fire and Marine Insurance company in the Court of Common Pleas for the Charleston District, South Carolina, for the loss of 28 slaves valued at $20,000 due to their emancipation from the ''Enterprise'' in Bermuda. through the British emancipation of slaves in the ''Enterprise'' (1835), ''Hermosa'' (1840) and ''Creole'' incidents.[https://books.google.com/books?id=ATq5_6h2AT0C&pg=PA340&lpg=PA340&dq=%22comet%22+slave+ship&source=bl&ots=5MQ7o4YOA1&sig=Le8D6jhftpteXZ8GrcyBK94raRo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=VQhgUarCGNGb0AXAvYG4Bg&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22comet%22%20slave%20ship&f=false "Hermosa Case (1840)"], ''The Historical Encyclopedia of World Slavery: A-K, Vol. II, L-Z, ed. Junius P. Rodriguez, ABC-CLIO, 1997, p. 340 A claims commission met in London from September 15, 1853 to January 15, 1855 to settle the amount of total awards covered under this treaty, which extended to a variety of claims dating from December 1814. In February 1855, Congress passed a bill accepting the commission's settlement and appropriating funds for the US payment required.[https://books.google.com/books?id=Wn01AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA447&lpg=PA447&dq=US-Great+Britain+mutual+reparation+treaty+of+1853&source=bl&ots=T8ePsjf4i3&sig=v_J0wowuCoJNUDIFyDXpV_JJMuU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eS9cUduYNYTwrQGq-ICYCw&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=US-Great%20Britain%20mutual%20reparation%20treaty%20of%201853&f=false Charles Henry Butler, ''The Treaty Making Power of the United States],'' Volume 2, New York: Banks Law Publishing Co., 1902, pp. 446-447. Quote: "Claims Convention. ''Concluded February 8, 1853, proclaimed August 1853.'' 10 Stat at L., Treaties, p. 110. U.S. Tr. and Con. 1889, p. 445[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1855/03/06/76458905.pdf "Acts of Congress/List of Acts and Resolutions Passed at the Second Session of the Thirty-third Congress"], ''New York Times'', 24 February 1855. Quote: "...Our Treaty on Claims with Great Britain: On motion of Mr. HOUSTON, the bill carrying into effect the treaty between the United States and Great Britain on the subject of claims, concluded February, 1853, was taken up...the commission provided for the payment of $270,700 against this Government, due British subjects, and $329,000 against the British Government, due to American citizens, requiring the money to be paid in one year from the expiration of the commission, which expired on the 15th of last month...The treaty has relation to slaves on board the ''Enterprise'' and ''Creole''. The bill passed under the operation of the previous question." ==Related incidents== British officials may have been warned off liberating slaves from US ships, but citizens sometimes acted independently. In 1855 the ''New York Times'' reported that an American slave had been removed by Jamaicans from the brig ''Young America'' at [[Savanna-la-Mar]] and "set at large". Although the action was taken by private individuals and not officials, the paper noted the potential for future conflict between the nations, and called for a lasting solution to be found by "the two governments interested".''New York Times'', 20 July 1855. ==In popular culture== *In 1852 the noted abolitionist [[Frederick Douglass]] published a novella called ''[[The Heroic Slave]]'', inspired by the ''Creole'' revolt featuring Washington. He stressed the personal aspects of the slaves' rebellion, placing it firmly within American revolutionary tradition.Sale, Maggie. "To Make the Past Useful: Frederick Douglass' Politics of Solidarity," ''Arizona Quarterly'' 52.3 (Autumn 1995): 25-60 ==Crew, passengers, and slaves on the ''Creole''== Officers: * Robert Ensor, of Richmond, VA, captain, wounded * Zephaniah C. McCargo, nephew of Thomas * Lewis, an old slave servant of Thomas McCargo * William Henry Merritt, slave trader * Jacob Miller Leaders of the slave revolt: * [[Madison Washington]] * Ben Blacksmith (Johnstone) * Elijah Morris * Doc Ruffin Participants: * Pompey Garrison * George Portlock * Tyler * Addison * T. Smallwood * William Glover * America Woodis * George Benton * Adam Carney * Reuben Knight * Jordan Philips ==Giddings Resolutions== Joshua Giddings introduced these resolutions in Congress in 1842 and was censured for opening debate on slavery in defiance of a ruling against it. He resigned and returned to his home state of Ohio, where he was quickly re-elected by his constituents in a special election. He soon returned to Congress. # Resolved, That, prior to the Adoption of the Federal Constitution, each of the several States composing this Union exercised full and exclusive jurisdiction over the subject of slavery within its own territory, and possessed full power to continue or abolish it at pleasure. # Resolved, That, by adopting the Constitution, no part of the aforesaid powers were delegated to the Federal Government, but were reserved by and still pertain to each of the several States. # Resolved, That, by the 8th section of the 1st article of the Constitution, each of the several States surrendered to the Federal Government all jurisdiction over the subjects of commerce and navigation upon the high seas. # Resolved. That slavery, being an abridgment of the natural rights of man, can exist only by force of positive ''municipal law,'' and is necessarily confined to the territorial jurisdiction of the power creating it. # Resolved, That when a ship belonging to the citizens of any State of the Union leaves the waters and territory of such State, and enters upon the high seas, the persons on board cease to be subject to the slave laws of such State, and therefore are governed in their relations to each other by, and are amenable to, the laws of the United States. # Resolved, That when the brig ''Creole'', on her late passage for New Orleans, left the territorial jurisdiction of Virginia, the slave laws of that State ceased to have jurisdiction over the persons on board such brig, and such persons became amenable only to the laws of the United States. # Resolved, That the persons on board the said ship, in resuming their natural rights of personal liberty, violated no law of the United States, incurred no legal responsibility, and are justly liable to no punishment. # Resolved, That all attempts to regain possession of or to re-enslave said persons are unauthorized by the Constitution or laws of the United States, and are incompatible with our national honor. # Resolved, That all attempts to exert our national influence in favor of the ''[[coastwise slave trade]]'', or to place this nation in the attitude of maintaining a "commerce in human beings", are subversive to the rights and injurious to the feelings of the free States, are unauthorized by the Constitution, and prejudicial to our national character. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * [https://books.google.com/books?id=XTLFKrmJPgcC&dq=%22children+of+the+enterprise%22+musson&source=gbs_navlinks_s Gerald Horne, ''Negro Comrades of the Crown: African Americans and the British Empire Fight the U.S. Before Emancipation''], New York University (NYU) Press, 2012 * [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14788810802149733?journalCode=rjas20#preview Johnson, Walter. "White lies: Human property and domestic slavery aboard the slave ship ''Creole''"], ''Atlantic Studies'' (ISSN 1478-8810), v. 5, no. 2 (Aug. 2008), pp. 237–263. * [http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/civil_war_history/v021/21.1.jones.pdf Jones, Howard. "The Peculiar Institution and National Honor: The Case of the Creole Slave Revolt"], ''Civil War History,'' 1975, pp. 28–50, at Project Muse, subscription. * [http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llhj&fileName=037/llhj037.db&recNum=566&itemLink=D?hlaw:4:./temp/~ammem_GIy2::@@@mdb=mcc,gottscho,detr,nfor,wpa,aap,cwar,bbpix,cowellbib,calbkbib,consrvbib,bdsbib,dag,fsaall,gmd,pan,vv,presp,varstg,suffrg,nawbib,horyd,wtc,toddbib,mgw,ncr,ngp,musdibib,hlaw,papr,lhbumbib,rbpebib,lbcoll,alad,hh,aaodyssey,magbell,bbc,dcm,raelbib,runyon,dukesm,lomaxbib,mtj,gottlieb,aep,qlt,coolbib,fpnas,aasm,denn,relpet,amss,aaeo,mff,afc911bib,mjm,mnwp,rbcmillerbib,molden,ww2map,mfdipbib,afcnyebib,klpmap,hawp,omhbib,rbaapcbib,mal,ncpsbib,ncpm,lhbprbib,ftvbib,afcreed,aipn,cwband,flwpabib,wpapos,cmns,psbib,pin,coplandbib,cola,tccc,curt,mharendt,lhbcbbib,eaa,haybib,mesnbib,fine,cwnyhs,svybib,mmorse,afcwwgbib,mymhiwebib,uncall,afcwip,mtaft,manz,llstbib,fawbib,berl,fmuever,cdn,upboverbib,mussm,cic,afcpearl,awh,awhbib,sgp,wright,lhbtnbib,afcesnbib,hurstonbib,mreynoldsbib,spaldingbib,sgproto,scsmbib,afccalbib%230370567&linkText=1 "Giddings Resolutions"], 1842, American Memory, Library of Congress ==Further reading== * Downey, Arthur T. {{Infobox music festival | name =Drop Dead Festival | image =File:Ddfcrowd.png | caption =Drop Dead Festival crowd | location =[[New York, NY]] and [[Europe]] with additional smaller events having formerly been held in [[Los Angeles]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Boston]], and [[New Jersey]] | years_active =2003-present | founders =NY Decay Productions | dates = | genre = [[Punk rock]], [[electronic music|electronic]], [[Experimental music|experimental]] | attendance = | capacity = | website = {{url|http://www.dropdeadfestival.com}} }} The '''Drop Dead Festival''' is the largest [[DIY]] festival for "art-damaged" music.<!-- What does that mean?? --> It has as many as 65 bands per event, and has been known to attract attendees from over 30 countries. Drop Dead is an [[electro music|electro]], [[post-punk]], [[electropunk]], and [[experimental music|experimental]] multiple-day festival, previously held in [[New York, NY]] and [[Europe]] with additional smaller events having formerly been held in [[Los Angeles]], [[Philadelphia]], [[Boston]], and [[New Jersey]]. The festival is also notable for its elaborate stage designs, bazaar of vendors of scene paraphernalia, movie screenings, and a dancefloor featuring underground DJs from around the world.<ref>[http://www.dropdeadfestival.com Drop Dead Festival] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060202072052/http://www.dropdeadfestival.com/ |date=February 2, 2006 }}</ref>
== History: USA 2003-2005== [[File:Dropdeadcrowd.jpg|thumb|left|260px|Crowd]] The first Drop Dead Festival was held in August 2003, after the success of a series of smaller events put on by NY Decay Productions at the Pyramid in [[New York City]]. The festival was originally held at the famous [[CBGB]] [[punk rock]] club, but subsequent Drop Dead Festivals moved to the much larger [[Knitting Factory]], also in lower [[Manhattan]]. Although the main event moved to larger locations, CBGB traditionally held pre-parties and after-parties for the festival until the club closed. In 2005, the Drop Dead Festival grew to four days, during [[Halloween]] week. Over 5,000 people attended this event, featuring headliner [[Nina Hagen]].
In 2006 the Drop Dead Festival was held at the Knitting Factory on [[Labor Day]] weekend, September 1–3. This was the last regular Drop Dead Festival in the US.
== 2007-2012 ==
Since 2007, Drop Dead has been held in Europe as a traveling festival, including Prague (2007), Portugal (2008), Lithuania (2010), and Berlin (2011, 2012).
==See also== {{Commons category|Drop Dead Festival}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]] *[[List of punk rock festivals]]

{{Infobox song | name = Ebeneezer Goode | cover = The Shamen - Ebeneezer Goode.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[The Shamen]] | album = [[Boss Drum]] | released = 24 August, 1992{{cite web|url=http://i.imgur.com/1jPGM6s.jpg|title=BPI > Certified Awards > Search results for 'Shamen'|publisher=[[British Phonographic Industry]]|accessdate=28 January 2016}} | format = Multiple | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Rave music|Rave]]{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/best-of-rave-westwood-mw0000997213|title=Best of Rave [Westwood] - Various Artists - Songs, Reviews, Credits - AllMusic|website=AllMusic|accessdate=26 August 2017}} | length = 3:53 | label = [[One Little Indian]] | writer = {{hlist|Colin Angus|[[Mr. C|Richard West]]}} | producer = | prev_title = [[LSI (Love Sex Intelligence)]] | prev_year = 1992 | next_title = Boss Drum | next_year = 1992 }} "'''Ebeneezer Goode'''" is a [[song]] by British electronic music group [[The Shamen]], which, after being heavily remixed by [[The Beatmasters]], became their biggest hit when released as a single in August 1992. The band's original version also featured on the vinyl edition of their album ''[[Boss Drum]]''. "Ebeneezer Goode" was one of the most controversial [[List of number-one singles from the 1990s (UK)|UK number-one hits]] of the 1990s, due to its perceived oblique endorsement of [[recreational drug use]]. The song was initially banned by the [[BBC]]. It has been claimed that the single was eventually withdrawn after the band were hounded by the [[British tabloid press]],{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/totp2/features/top5/drug_songs.shtml |title=Top of the Pops 2 - Top 5 Drug Songs |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2014-03-30}} though according to The Shamen themselves, it was deleted while at Number 1 due to its long chart run 'messing up our release schedule'.{{cite web|author=Interviews by Dave Simpson |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/mar/05/ebeneezer-goode-shamen |title=How we made ... Ebeneezer Goode by the Shamen |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2014-03-30}} == Lyrics == The song is best known for its chorus, "'Eezer Goode, 'Eezer Goode / He's Ebeneezer Goode", the first part of which is audibly identical to, "Es are good" – 'E' being common slang for the drug [[MDMA|ecstasy]]. However, 'E' is also sung many other times during the song, ostensibly as '''e'' (i.e. ''he''), such as in "E's sublime, E makes you feel fine". The lyrics allude to the advantages of the drug, though with an admonition against excessive use: {{cquote|A gentleman of leisure, he's there for your pleasure
But go easy on old 'Eezer, he's a love you could lose
Extraordinary fella, like [[Punch and Judy|Mister Punchinella]]
He's the kind of geezer who must never be abused.}} The song also contains references to [[Roll-your-own cigarette|hand-rolled cigarettes]] with the lines "Has anybody got any Veras?" ("[[Vera Lynn]]s" being [[rhyming slang]] for "skins" or [[rolling paper]]s) and "Got any salmon?" ("salmon and trout" being rhyming slang for "snout" or [[tobacco]]). The "A great philosopher once wrote.." sample at the start of the song is [[Malcolm McDowell]] from Lindsay Anderson's 1973 film ''[[O Lucky Man!]]'' ==Music video== The video consisted of club scenes intermixed with a caped man (ostensibly Ebeneezer Goode himself, played by [[Jerry Sadowitz]]) running round a wasteland. Due to the use of flashing images in the video, some music channels include epilepsy warnings over the video. Some channels, including [[VH1 (UK and Ireland)|VH1]], edit the video to reduce the frame rate of these scenes which deletes each bright frame. The music video was played in episode 5 and 6, season 3 of ''[[Beavis and Butt-head]]'', "Kidnapped". ==Performance on ''Top of the Pops''== When the Shamen appeared on BBC One's ''[[Top of the Pops]]'', it was expected that [[Mr C]] should tone down the song due to its being broadcast. The group replaced the final lyric "Got any salmon?" with "Has anyone got any [[underlay]]?" He was later asked about this in a radio interview, to which he replied that it was not a drug reference but a ''rug'' reference.Bussmann, Jane: ''Once In A Lifetime: The Crazy Days of Acid House'' ({{ISBN|0-7535-0260-7}}) ==Chart performance== The song entered the [[UK Singles Chart]] at number six in September 1992, before climbing to number one two weeks later (during the BBC's drug awareness week), staying there for four weeks.{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= [[British Hit Singles & Albums]] | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | pages= 544–5}} It was the 13th biggest selling single of 1992, selling 278,000 copies. It is the group's biggest seller. ==Charts and sales== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Peak positions=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Chart (1992/93) !Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Australia|14|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Austria|11|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Flanders|23|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- |Denmark ([[IFPI Denmark|IFPI]]){{cite web|url=http://americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Music-and-Media/90s/1992/MM-1992-11-28.pdf|title=Top 10 Denmark|publisher=[[Music & Media]]|accessdate=2018-03-21}} |align="center"|9 |- |Finland ([[Suomen virallinen lista]]){{cite book|first= Timo |last= Pennanen |year= 2006 |title= Sisältää hitin - levyt ja esittäjät Suomen musiikkilistoilla vuodesta 1972 |language= fi |edition= 1st |publisher= Tammi |isbn= 978-951-1-21053-5 |location= Helsinki}} |align="center"|8 |- {{singlechart|France|43|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Germany|23|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- |Ireland ([[Irish Singles Chart|IRMA]]){{cite web|title=Irish Single Chart, database |url=http://www.irishcharts.ie/search/placement |publisher=irishcharts |accessdate=11 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hFf8iFDu?url=http://www.irishcharts.ie/search/placement |archivedate=3 June 2009 |df= }} | style="text-align:center;"|1 |- {{singlechart|Dutch40|19|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|New Zealand|23|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Norway|2|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Sweden|11|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- {{singlechart|Swiss|17|artist=Shamen|song=Ebeneezer Goode}} |- |UK Singles ([[The Official Charts Company]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/26087/shamen/|title=Official Charts > Shamen|publisher=The Official UK Charts Company|accessdate=16 January 2016}} | style="text-align:center;"|1 |} {{col-2}} ===Certifications=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Country !Certification !Date !Sales certified |- |Australia{{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988-2010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt.
