Only a few days later,{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-26/245302-south-sudan-fighting-despite-cease-fire.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8|title=South Sudan fighting despite cease-fire|publisher=The Daily Star|date=26 January 2014}} the rebels accused that a government takeover of Leer was a deliberate attempt to sabotage the second round of talks that were to start later in February.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Feb-02/246101-government-retakes-machars-hometown-say-south-sudan-rebels.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8|title=Government retakes Machar's hometown, say South Sudan rebels|work=The Daily Star|date=2 February 2014}} The rebels threatened to boycott the second round talks, demanding the release of four remaining political prisoners and the withdrawal of Ugandan troops.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Feb-10/246891-south-sudan-peace-talks-postponed-officials.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8|title=South Sudan peace talks postponed: officials|work=The Daily Star|date=10 February 2014}} Later in February, the rebels attacked the strategic government controlled Malakal{{cite news|url = http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Feb-18/247684-fresh-fighting-breaks-out-in-south-sudan.ashx |title = Fresh fighting breaks out in South Sudan|work=The Daily Star| place = LB | date=18 February 2014| first =Ilya | last = Garidneff}} and the government admitted withdrawal{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/south-sudan-government-forces-recapture-malakal/1875677.html|title=S. Sudan admits to tactical withdrawal in Malakal|publisher=sudantribune.com|date=21 February 2014|accessdate=2 September 2015}} and then, in March, the rebels admitted withdrawal, changing hands for the fifth time.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/south-sudan-government-forces-recapture-malakal/1875677.html |title=South Sudan Government Forces Say Malakal Recaptured|publisher=voanews.com|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=2 September 2015}} In April, rebels claimed once again to have seized Bentiu{{cite news|url=http://m.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-27037336?ocid=socialflow_twitter|title=South Sudan conflict: Pro-Machar forces 'seize' Bentiu|work=BBC|date=15 April 2014}} and by April 19 South Sudan's army admitted to have "lost communication" with commanders battling in Unity state.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Apr-19/253886-south-sudan-army-battles-rebels-in-worsening-war.ashx#axzz2yAxIQt2k|title=South Sudan army battles rebels in worsening war|work=The Daily Star|date=19 April 2014}} The [[2014 Bentiu massacre]] occurred on 15 April in Bentiu when more than 200 civilians, all said to have been Dinkas,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27108777|title=South Sudan rebels deny Bentiu slaughter accusation|work=BBC News}} were massacred by Nuer rebels. A mosque, hospital, and church were targeted where civilians had sought refuge from the fighting. After the fall of Bentiu, [[Salva Kiir]] sacked Army chief [[James Hoth Mai]] and replaced him with [[Paul Malong Awan]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27137000|title=South Sudan President Salva Kiir sacks army chief|date=24 April 2014|accessdate=24 July 2014|publisher=BBC}} [[File:Greater Pibor Administrative Area.svg|thumb|left|The [[Greater Pibor Administrative Area]] (highlighted) created as part of a peace agreement between the government and the largely [[Murle people|Murle]] rebel group, the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]], in 2014.]] In May 2014, the government signed a peace agreement called the Greater Pibor Administrative Area peace agreement with the largely [[Murle people|Murle]] group, the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]] of the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement]], led by [[David Yau Yau]]. As part of the agreement, a semi-autonomous area called the [[Greater Pibor Administrative Area]] was created to increase the minority populations within its borders and David Yau Yau was appointed chief administrator, equivalent to state governor.{{cite web |url=http://www.smallarmssurveysudan.org/fileadmin/docs/working-papers/HSBA-WP35-Greater-Pibor.pdf| title=Real but Fragile:The Greater Pibor Administrative Area| work=small arms survey | date=March 2015| accessdate=22 October 2016}} In February 2015, a largely [[Murle people|Murle]] group, unhappy with the agreement with the government, split off from the Cobra Faction to form the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Greater Pibor Forces]] and declared allegiance to Machar. One of their disagreements with the government was the alleged provoking of the Murle to fight against anti-government Nuer groups in Jonglei.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article53980|title=Murle faction announces defection to S. Sudan rebels|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=18 January 2017|date=14 February 2015}} In April 2016, [[Murle people|Murle]] fighters in South Sudan crossed over to [[Gambela Region|Gambela]] in [[Ethiopia]] and [[Ethnic violence in South Sudan#2016 Gambela raid|killed more than 200 people]], stole 2000 cattle and kidnapped more than 100 children from the [[Nuer people|Nuer]] tribe.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/blogs/africa/2016/04/ethiopia-attack-wife-child-ran-160422164613438.html|title=Ethiopia attack: 'I took my wife and child and ran'|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=18 July 2016|date=22 April 2016}} On 9 May 2014, President Salva Kiir and Riek Machar signed the second ceasefire in [[Addis Ababa]], a one-page agreement recommitting to the first ceasefire.{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-27352902# | title=South Sudan rivals Kiir and Machar agree peace deal | work=BBC | date=9 May 2014 | accessdate=10 May 2014}} Hostilities were to end in 24 hours while a permanent ceasefire would be worked on and it promised to open humanitarian corridors and allow "30 days of tranquility" so farmers can sow crops and prevent famine. Hours after the ceasefire was to be in effect, both sides accused each other of violating the ceasefire.{{cite news|title=South Sudan ceasefire violated, rebels and government say|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27362508|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=BBC News|date=11 May 2014}} On 11 June 2014, both parties agreed to begin talks on the formation of a transitional government within 60 days and to a third ceasefire refraining from combat during this period.[https://online.wsj.com/articles/south-sudan-peace-talks-reach-apparent-breakthrough-1402473616 South Sudan Peace Talks Reach Apparent Breakthrough] ''Wall Street Journal''. 11 June 2014. Accessed 13 June 2014 However, the talks collapsed as both sides boycotted the talks,[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/06/s-sudan-warring-sides-boycott-peace-talks-201461701426722700.html S Sudan's warring sides boycott peace talks] Al Jazeera. 17 Jun 2014. Accessed 19 June 2014 and by 16 June, the ceasefire was reported to have been violated.[http://allafrica.com/stories/201406171015.html South Sudan: AUPSC Condemns Violation of South Sudan's Ceasefire Deal] Sudan Tribune. 16 June 2014. Accessed 19 June 2014 In August 2014, Kiir and leaders of South Sudan's neighbouring states sign a roadmap leading to a transitional government of national unity. Machar refuses to sign up, accusing leaders in the IGAD, a regional group involved in the negotiations, of tilting the process in favour of Kiir. In November 2014, both parties renew the much-broken ceasefire and IGAD mediators give them 15 days to reach a power-sharing deal, threatening sanctions if they fail. This third ceasefire breaks down 24 hours later with fighting in the oil-rich north. In January 2015, rival factions sign a reunification agreement in [[Arusha]], Tanzania, but fighting continued. In February 2015, Kiir and Machar signed a document on "Areas of Agreement" for a future transitional government of national unity and recommitted themselves to the ceasefire. The talks later collapsed and fighting broke out in March.{{cite news|title= South Sudan peace talks suspended indefinitely| url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/south-sudan-peace-talks-suspended-indefinitely-150306124303011.html |accessdate = 6 March 2015| publisher = Al Jazeera|date=6 March 2015}}{{cite news|title= South Sudan peace talks break up, mediator berates leaders| url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/06/us-southsudan-unrest-idUSKBN0M216A20150306 |accessdate = 6 March 2015| publisher = Reuters|date=6 March 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/south-sudan-troops-rebel-fighters-clash-after-peace-talks-fail-1425719995|title=South Sudan Troops, Rebel Fighters Clash After Peace Talks Fail|author=Nicholas Bariyo|date=7 March 2015|work=WSJ}} [[Johnson Olony]] led a militia that planned to be integrated into the SPLM government forces, but he switched to oppose the government when the government announced plans to carve up new states which the Shilluk felt was to divide their homeland. On 16 May 2015, Olony's militia and elements of the SPLM-IO captured Upper Nile's capital, [[Malakal]], as well as Anakdiar and areas around [[Kodok]].{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/s-sudan-rebels-johnson-olony-our-side|title=S Sudan rebels: Johnson Olony is on our side|publisher=radiotamazuj.org|accessdate=2015-06-23|date=2015-05-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623121013/https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/s-sudan-rebels-johnson-olony-our-side|archivedate=23 June 2015|df=dmy-all}} His Shilluk militia group now called itself the 'Agwelek forces'. The group said they want to run their affairs independently from others in [[Upper Nile State]], and SPLM-IO backed away from claims that it is in charge of Olony's group and stated that Olony's interests simply coincides with theirs.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/machar-backs-away-claim-loyalty-independent-shilluk-forces|title=Machar backs away from claim to loyalty of 'independent' Shilluk forces|publisher=radiotamazuj.org|accessdate=2015-06-23|date=2015-05-18|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623142055/https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/machar-backs-away-claim-loyalty-independent-shilluk-forces|archivedate=23 June 2015|df=dmy-all}} SPLM-IO said they understood the feeling from the [[Shilluk people|Shilluk]] community that they wanted a level of independence and that that was the reason the SPLM-IO last year created Fashoda state for the Shilluk kingdom and appointed Tijwog Aguet, a Shilluk, as governor. On 11 August 2015, [[Gabriel Tang]],{{cite web|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/top-rebel-commander-killed-clashes-upper-nile|title=Top rebel commander killed in clashes in Upper Nile|publisher=Radio Tamazuj|accessdate=6 January 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109191115/https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/top-rebel-commander-killed-clashes-upper-nile|archivedate=9 January 2017|df=dmy-all}} Gathoth Gatkuoth, the former SPLM-IO logistics chief, and rebel commander Peter Gadet, announced that they and other powerful commanders had split from Riek Machar, and rejected ongoing peace talks, announcing that they would now combat Riek Machar's forces in addition to government forces. Gathoth Gatkuoth states he wishes for a President who is neither Dinka nor Nuer and intended to register his group as a political group called the "Federal Democractic Party" and that their forces would be called the "South Sudan National Army". === Compromise Peace Agreement and second Juba clashes (2015–16)=== [[File:28 States of South Sudan within regions.png|thumb|200px|In December 2015, Kiir increased the number of states from 10 to 28 and appointed governors considered loyal to him.]] {{See also|2016 Juba clashes|2016–18 Wau clashes}} In late August 2015, Salva Kiir signed a peace agreement previously signed by Riek Machar called the "Compromise Peace Agreement" mediated by [[IGAD]] +. The agreement would make Riek Machar the vice-president again.{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/101918/is-south-sudan-s-latest-peace-accord-the-real-deal|title=Is South Sudan's latest peace accord the real deal?|publisher=irinnews.org|accessdate=30 August 2015|date=26 August 2015}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-34069032|title=Will South Sudan peace deal be worth the wait?|publisher=bbcnews.com|accessdate=26 August 2015|date=26 August 2015}} The agreement established the Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (JMEC) responsible for monitoring and overseeing implementation of the agreement. On 20 October 2015, [[Uganda]] announced that it will voluntarily withdraw its soldiers from South Sudan, in accordance to that peace agreement.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/uganda-begins-troop-withdrawal-from-south-sudan/3018884.html|title=Uganda Begins Troop Withdrawal from South Sudan|last=Clottey|first=Peter|date=22 October 2015|work=VOA News|via=|accessdate=22 October 2015}} In January 2016, David Yau Yau dissolved the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]] of the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement]] and joined the SPLM.{{cite news|url=http://www.gurtong.net/ECM/Editorial/tabid/124/ctl/ArticleView/mid/519/articleId/18307/Yau-Yau-Dissolves-Party-And-Officially-Joins-SPLM.aspx|title=Yau Yau Dissolves Party And Officially Joins SPLM|publisher=gurtong.net|accessdate=22 October 2016|date=12 January 2016}} In January Gathoth Gatkuoth joined with the government but was dismissed by his Federal Democratic Party for doing so.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article57596|title=Changson dismisses Gathoth Gatkuoth as FDP group splits over advance team to Juba|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=9 January 2017}} In April 2016, as part of the peace deal, Machar returned to Juba with troops loyal to him and was sworn in as vice-president.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36140423|title=South Sudan rebel chief Riek Machar sworn in as vice-president|publisher=bbcnews.com|accessdate=26 April 2016|date=26 April 2016}} [[File:Wau refugee camp 2.png|thumb|left|Refugee camp at [[Wau, South Sudan|Wau town]]'s cathedral, where many [[Dār Fertit|Fertit]] have sought protection during the [[2016–18 Wau clashes]].]] On Christmas Eve 2015, Salva Kiir announced he was going forward with a plan to increase the number of [[States of South Sudan|state]]s from 10 to 28 and then, five days later, swore in all new governors appointed by him and considered loyal to him.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/01/22/south-sudan-next-civil-war-is-starting-shilluk-army/|title=South Sudan's next civil war is starting|publisher=foreignpolicy.com|accessdate=23 January 2016|date=22 January 2016}} The new borders give Kiir's Dinkas a majority in strategic locations. Some observers feel that the government is holding on to the peace deal to maintain international aid while backing campaigns to increase Dinka control over land and resources traditionally held by other groups.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/jul/05/violence-erupts-again-in-south-sudan-wau-as-faith-in-peace-deal-flounders|title=Violence erupts again in South Sudan as faith in peace deal flounders|publisher=the guardian|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=5 July 2016}} As the predominantly Shilluk Agwelek forces joined, in July 2016, with the SPLM-IO, which entered the peace agreement with the government, some Shilluk felt dissatisfied. After the establishment of the new states, a new group made up of mostly Shilluk formed the "[[Tiger Faction New Forces]]" (TFNF) in October 2015, led by General Yohanis Okiech.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article56894|title=New rebel group formed in South Sudan against the creation of 28 states|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=15 December 2016|date=30 October 2015}} They rejected joining the SPLM-IO or the peace agreement and called for the restoration of the original 1956 borders of the Shilluk territories.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?iframe&page=imprimable&id_article=58273|title=Tiger faction of ethnic Shilluk kingdom dismisses integration into SPLM-IO|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=15 December 2016|date=11 March 2016}} When Dinka cattle herders, allegedly backed by the SPLA, occupied farmland, [[Azande]] youth rose up into militias mostly with the [[Arrow Boys]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/dec/07/south-sudan-horrific-attacks-prompt-communities-take-arms|title=Horrific attacks prompt South Sudan's communities to form armed groups|publisher=the guardian|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=7 December 2015}} whose leader Alfred Karaba Futiyo Onyang declared allegiance to SPLM-IO{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article57042|title=SPLA-IO welcomes Arrow Boys to its fighting force|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=13 December 2016|date=15 November 2015}} and claimed to have occupied parts of Western Equatoria.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article57377|title=Arrow Boys say they occupy several areas of Western Equatoria state|publisher=Sudan Tribune|accessdate=13 December 2016|date=15 December 2015}} A new rebel faction calling itself the [[South Sudan Federal Democratic Party]] (different from but related to the larger similarly named rebel faction led by [[Peter Gadet]], Gabriel Chang and Gathoth Gatkuoth), made up mostly of [[Lotuko people]] formed during this time due to growing perceptions of mistreatment by the "Dinka" government and took over a SPLA outpost in Eastern Equatoria.{{cite web|url=https://www.crisisgroup.org/africa/horn-africa/south-sudan/south-sudan-s-south-conflict-equatorias|title=South Sudan's South:Conflict in the Equatorias|publisher=[[International Crisis Group]]|accessdate=9 January 2016|date=25 May 2016}} In February 2016, Dinka SPLA soldiers attacked a UN camp targeting Nuer and Shilluk who accused the government of annexing parts of their ancestral land.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/apr/26/un-bases-south-sudan-malakal-attack-blessing-curse-unmiss|title=UN bases in South Sudan are 'a blessing and a curse'|accessdate=7 July 2016|date=26 April 2016}} About a year after the peace agreement was signed, groups of ethnic Dinka youth and the SPLA targeted members of the [[Dār Fertit|Fertit]] in [[Wau, South Sudan|Wau]], killing dozens and forcing more than 120,000 to flee their homes.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/south-sudan-dozens-killed-violence-flares-wau-160703063621236.html|title=South Sudan: Dozens killed as violence flares in Wau|publisher=aljazeera|accessdate=4 July 2016|date=3 July 2016}} As result, local Fertit tribal militias and groups allied with the SPLM-IO rose in rebellion, causing heavy [[2016–17 Wau clashes|clashes]] in the originally relatively peaceful [[Wau State]], which continued for months. [[File:SPLA soldiers near Juba (April 2016) 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Sudan People's Liberation Army|SPLA]] soldiers near [[Juba]], shortly after the [[2016 Juba clashes|clashes in the city]] between followers of [[Riek Machar]] and [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]].]] [[2016 Juba clashes|Violence erupted in July 2016]] after an attack outside of where President Kiir and Riek Machar were meeting in [[Juba]]. Fighting spread throughout the city. Over 300 people were killed and over 40 people were injured, including civilians.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/amp/news/2016/07/south-sudan-scores-dead-independence-anniversary-160709090438275.html|title=S Sudan: More than 100 dead on independence anniversary|publisher=}} In the following week, 26,000 fled to neighboring Uganda. [[Indian Air Force]] evacuated Indian citizens from the country under [[Operation Sankat Mochan (India)|Operation Sankat Mochan]].{{cite web | author= | title=Sankat Mochan: First aircraft with evacuated people from Juba to land in Kerala tomorrow | website=The Indian Express | date=14 July 2016 | url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/operation-sankat-mochan-genral-vk-singh-evacuted-indians-to-reach-kerala-2914183/ | accessdate=16 July 2016}} A spokesman for Riek Machar announced that South Sudan was "back to war" and that opposition forces based in areas of Juba had been attacked by forces loyal to the President.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36758013|title=South Sudan 'back to war', says VP Riek Machar's spokesman|publisher=BBC News}} Fighting involving heavy machine guns, mortars and tanks was reported in several parts of Juba on 10 July. Gun battles broke out near the airport and a UN base forcing the airport to close for safety reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/south-sudan-fighting-gunfire-erupts-juba-160710064423699.html|title=South Sudan fighting: Gunfire erupts again in Juba|publisher=Aljazeera|date=10 July 2016}} President Salva Kiir and first Vice-President Riek Machar ordered a ceasefire after days of intense violence.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36763076|title=South Sudan clashes: Salva Kiir and Riek Machar order ceasefire|date=11 July 2016|publisher=BBC}} Machar fled Juba after the clashes. After a 48-hour ultimatum given by Kiir for Machar to return to Juba to progress with the peace agreement talks passed, the SPLA-IO in Juba appointed lead negotiator [[Taban Deng Gai]] to replace Machar and the government accepted him as acting vice-president. Machar said any talks would be illegal because Machar had previously fired Gai.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/south-sudan-opposition-replaces-missing-leader-machar-160723144856580.html|title=South Sudan opposition replaces missing leader Machar|date=23 July 2016|publisher=aljazeera}} Machar, with assistance from the UN, went to exile, first to [[Kinshasa]]{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37116862|title=South Sudan conflict: Sacked VP Riek Machar goes into exole|publisher=bbcnews.com|accessdate=19 August 2016|date=18 August 2016}} then to Sudan and then to South Africa, where he was allegedly{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/apr/16/south-sudan-could-britain-create-peace-striking-how-close-they-feel|title=How factions in South Sudan’s war took shape on British campuses|date=16 April 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017|publisher=The Guardian}} kept in [[house arrest]].{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/01/02/the-revenge-of-salva-kiir-south-sudan-genocide-ethnic-cleansing/|title=The revenge of Salva Kiir|date=2 January 2017|publisher=foreignpolicy}} ===Renewed conflict and rebel infighting (2016–17)=== {{See also|Pagak offensive}} [[File:SPLA-IO soldiers (Juba - April 2016).jpg|thumb|left|Rebel soldiers of the [[Sudan People's Liberation Movement-in-Opposition|SPLA-IO]] in April 2016.]] In September 2016, Machar announced a call for armed struggle against Kiir{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-riek-machar-calls-for-armes-struggle/3525045.html|title=South Sudan's Riek Machar Calls for Armed Struggle|date=26 September 2016|publisher=Voice of America}} and in November, he said SPLM-IO would not participate in a workshop organized by JMEC, saying the peace agreement needs to be revised. In September, [[Lam Akol]], leader of the largest opposition party, [[Democratic Change (South Sudan)|Democratic Change]], announced a new faction called the National Democratic Movement (NDM) to overthrow Kiir.{{cite web|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/lam-akol-forms-rebel-movement-fight-south-sudan-government|title=Lam Akol forms rebel movement to fight South Sudan government|date=27 September 2016|publisher=Radio Tamazuj}} Yohanis Okiech, who led the largely Shilluk Tiger Faction New Forces, which split from Uliny's Agwelek forces, joined the predominantly Shilluk NDM{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61355|title=S.Sudan rebel commander says rivalry undermines struggle|date=10 January 2017|publisher=Sudan Tribune}} as deputy chief of general staff.{{cite web|url=http://www.nyamile.com/2017/01/07/breaking-news-spla-io-gunned-down-ndms-gen-yohanis-okiech-in-upper-nile/t|title=SPLA-IO gunned down NDM's Gen. Yohanis Okiech in Upper Nile|date=7 January 2017|publisher=Nyamilepdia}} In the same month, the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement#SSDM/A - Cobra Faction|Cobra Faction]] of the [[South Sudan Democratic Movement]], now led by Khalid Boutros declared war against the government.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/militant-faction-vows-again-to-fight-south-sudan-government/3527442.html|title=Militant Faction Vows Again to Fight S. Sudan Government|date=27 September 2016|publisher=Voice of America}} On the international front, the African Union, after the Juba clashes, backed plans for the deployment of troops from regional nations with a strong mandate similar to that of the [[United Nations Force Intervention Brigade]] that swiftly defeated the [[March 23 Movement|M23 rebel]]s in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] as UN troops presently within the country have struggled to protect civilians.{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-36833875|title=South Sudan conflict: African Union approves regional force|date=19 July 2016|publisher=bbcnews}} In August 2016, the UN [[Security Council]] authorized such a force for Juba. The government initially opposed the move, claiming a violation of sovereignty.{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37065836|title=UN okays Juba troop deployment as South Sudan objects|date=12 August 2016|publisher=bbcnews}} With a resolution threatening an arms embargo if it blocked the new deployment, the government accepted the move with conditions such as the troops not being from neighboring countries, claiming they have interests at stake.{{cite news|title=S. Sudan's Otuho rebels unveil objectives for armed struggle|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article60149|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Sudan Tribune|date=7 September 2016}} They also accepted a hybrid court to investigate war crimes.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/south-sudan-agrees-accept-4000-peacekeepers-160904184808077.html|title=South Sudan accepts 4,000 more UN peacekeepers|date=5 September 2016|publisher=aljazeera}} The US pushed for an arms embargo and sanctions on Machar and army chief [[Paul Malong Awan]] through the Security Council, but it failed to receive enough votes to pass in December 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/us-seeks-sanctions-on-south-sudan-rebel-leader-army-chief/2016/11/18/95a75fd4-ae11-11e6-8f19-21a1c65d2043_story.html|title=US seeks sanctions on South Sudan rebel leader, army chief|date=19 November 2016|publisher=washington post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/12/outrage-blocks-south-sudan-arms-embargo-161223153844996.html|title=Outrage after UN blocks South Sudan arms embargo|date=24 December 2016|publisher=Aljazeera}} After an independent report into [[UNMISS]]'s failure to protect civilians in the Juba clashes, Secretary-General Ban sacked the commander of the UN force Lt Gen Johnson Mogoa Kimani Ondieki in November{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-37840961|title=UN sacks South Sudan peacekeeping chief over damning report|date=1 November 2016|work=BBC}} and then the general's native Kenya declared that it would pull out of the key role it plays in the peace process{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/11/fears-kenya-deports-south-sudan-rebel-spokesman-161104164614835.html|title=Fears after Kenya deports South Sudan rebel spokesman|date=4 November 2016|work=Al jazeera}} and withdrew its more than 1000 peacekeepers from UNMISS{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/11/kenya-withdraws-troops-mission-south-sudan-161102165506898.html|title=Kenya withdraws troops from UN mission in South Sudan|date=2 November 2016|work=Al jazeera}} before sending the troops back in with the start of the new UN secretary general's tenure.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/kenyan-troops-return-s-sudan-after-persuasion-un-chief|title=Kenya troops return to South Sudan after persuasion by UN chief|date=30 January 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}} On 30 April 2017, the first batch of the Regional Protection Force arrived under Brigadier General Jean Mupenzi of Rwanda{{cite news|url=http://sudantribune.com/spip.php?article62331|title=South Sudan welcomes arrival of first batch of regional protection force|date=1 May 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}} with the first phase of troops arriving in August.{{cite news|url=http://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=57323#.WY39nkkzp1t|title=South Sudan: Deployment of UN-mandated regional protection force begins|date=8 August 2017|accessdate=11 August 2017|work=United Nations}} Among regional powers, Kiir met, in January 2017, with Egyptian president [[Abdel Fattah el-Sisi]] who also met with Kiir’s ally Ugandan President Museveni. Egypt had previously rejected the [[Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam]] that Egypt feels would diminish its share of the [[Nile River]] and Ethiopian Prime Minister, [[Hailemariam Desalegn]] had accused Egyptian institutions of supporting terrorist groups in Ethiopia.{{cite news|title=South Sudan denies striking anti-Ethiopia deal|url= http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61421|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=Sudan Tribune|date=18 January 2017}} SPLM-IO alleged that a "dirty deal" was struck between Kiir and Egypt against Ethiopia while Kiir denied any diplomatic row.{{cite news|title= South Sudan presidency denies diplomatic row with Ethiopia|url= https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/south-sudan-presidency-denies-diplomatic-row-ethiopia |accessdate=4 February 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj|date=27 January 2017}} SPLM-IO accused the Egyptian Air Force of bombing their positions on February 4, 2017 while Egypt denied it.{{cite news|title=Egyptian Air Force bombs South Sudanese rebels in Upper Nile|url=http://www.southsudannewsagency.com/index.php/2017/02/03/egyptian-air-force-bombs-south-sudanese-rebels-upper-nile/|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=South Sudan News Agency|date=4 February 2017}} As a result of Sudan’s effective counterinsurgency strategy in the [[War in Darfur]], the biggest rebel faction, the [[Justice and Equality Movement]] (JEM), retreated to South Sudan and became involved in mercenary and criminal activities according to a UN report.{{cite news|title=UN: Two Darfur rebel groups retreat to Libya, South Sudan|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/un-two-darfur-rebel-groups-retreat-libya-south-sudan|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj|date=18 January 2017}} SPLM-IO accused JEM as well as another rebel group in Sudan, SPLM-North of joining the conflict on the side of Juba. Since the July clashes, the fighting spread from the [[Greater Upper Nile]] to include the previously safe haven of [[Equatoria]], where the bulk of SPLM-IO forces went for shelter from the clashes in Juba, located in Equatoria.{{cite web|url=https://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2016/11/14/who-can-stop-threat-genocide-south-sudan|title=Who can stop the threat of genocide in South Sudan?|date=14 November 2016|publisher=irinnews.org}} As Equatoria is the agricultural belt of the country, the number of people facing starvation soared to 6 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/11/starvation-threat-numbers-soar-south-sudan-161125134045296.html|title=Starvation threat numbers soar in South Sudan|date=25 November 2016|publisher=aljazzera}} In November 2016, SPLM-IO claimed to have taken of the towns Bazi, Morobo and Kaljak.{{cite web|url=http://sudantribune.com/spip.php?article60864|title=SPLA-IO rebels claim capture of three areas in S. Sudan|date=17 November 2016|publisher=Sudan Tribune}} While the rebels were mostly in retreat in the upper nile front, the rebels had gained ground on the Equatorian front where the SPLA was mostly restricted to its garrisons. This was attributed to local self-defence militias becoming increasingly integrated and the depopulation of towns resulting in the army having fewer supplies even while the rebels were already adapted to the bush.{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/special-report/2017/07/12/war-equatoria|title=The war in Equatoria|date=12 July 2017|accessdate=11 August 2017|work=irinnews}} However, after the fall of the main rebel headquarters of Pagak in the summer, the Southern headquarters in Lasu fell on 18 December 2017.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/19/world/africa/south-sudan-army-rebels-peace-talks.html|title=South Sudan Army Makes Push Against Rebels as Peace Talks Begin|date=19 December 2017|accessdate=22 December 2017|work=New York Times}} In late May, Kiir declared a unilateral ceasefire, which was taken with suspicion by others as it came after the late April government offensive that retook much territory and before the rainy season that would have anyway reduced fighting.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-security-un-idUSKBN18K2RH| work=Reuters| title=U.S., Britain, U.N. wary of South Sudan ceasefire announcement| date=24 May 2017|accessdate=15 June 2017}} Three days after the government retook Lasu it signed another ceasefire with the rebels in December 2017.{{cite news| url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-implement-cease-fire-saturday/4173979.html| work=Voice of America| title=South Sudan to Implement Cease-fire Saturday| date=21 December 2017|accessdate=22 December 2017}} The other major front of the conflict remained the Greater Upper Nile, where government forces mostly fought [[John Uliny]]'s SPLA-IO allied Agwelek forces. In a study of casualties up to early 2018, the deaths from violence peaked during this time between 2016-2017.{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-toll/study-estimates-190000-people-killed-in-south-sudans-civil-war-idUSKCN1M626R| work=Reuters| title=Study estimates 190,000 people killed in South Sudan's civil war| date=26 September 2018|accessdate=26 September 2018}} In October 2016, the rebels attempted to take Malakal{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/17/south-sudan-at-least-56-rebels-four-government-soldiers-killed|title=South Sudan: at least 56 rebels and four SPLA soldiers killed in clashes|date=17 October 2016|publisher=the guardian}} and by January 2017, fighting there had led to civilians deserting the country's second largest city.{{cite web|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/unmiss-situation-remains-tense-malakal-after-fighting|title=UNMISS: Situation remains tense in Malakal after fighting|date=30 January 2017|publisher=radio tamazuj}} In fighting in the [[Bahr el Ghazal (region of South Sudan)|Bahr el Ghazal]] region, pro-government militia [[Mathiang Anyoor]] attacked [[Wau, South Sudan|Wau]] killing up to 50 civilians in April 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/04/13/south-sudans-silent-slaughter-dinka-massacre-unchecked-by-regional-international-groups.html|title=South Sudan's silent slaughter: Dinka massacre unchecked by regional, international groups|date= 13 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Fox News}} In the same month, SPLA-IO captured [[Raga, South Sudan|Raja]], the capital of [[Lol State]], while state governor [[Rezik Zechariah Hassan|Hassan]] claimed the city was immediately retaken.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-rebels-allied-riek-machar-take-control-raja/3810797.html|title=South Sudan Rebels Allied With Machar Take Control of Raja|date=14 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Voice of America}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article62192|title=South Sudan governor says repulsed rebel attack on Raja|date=15 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}} A counteroffensive by the government starting in late April 2017 reversed most rebel gains,{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article62373|title=South Sudan army captures rebel headquarters in Raja: minister|date=6 May 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}} captured the capital of the Shilluk kingdom, [[Kodok]], from Uliny{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/new-south-sudan-fighting-displaces-25-000-people/420498483/|title=New South Sudan fighting displaces 25,000 people|date=26 April 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=Star Tribune}} and [[Pagak offensive|closed in on Pagak]], which had been the SPLA-IO headquarters since 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-war-idUSKBN19S2VG|title=Clashes near South Sudan rebel stronghold, aid workers evacuated|date=7 July 2017|accessdate=8 July 2017|work=Reuters}}{{cite web | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-war-idUSKBN19S2VG | title=Clashes near South Sudan rebel stronghold, aid workers evacuated | publisher=Reuters | date=7 July 2017 | accessdate=3 August 2017}} In July 2017, SPLA along with forces loyal to Taban Deng Gai took over the rebel-held town of [[Maiwut]].{{cite web | url=http://africatimes.com/2017/07/09/far-too-little-to-celebrate-as-south-sudan-observes-its-independence/ | title=Far too little to celebrate as South Sudan observes its independence | publisher=Africa Times | date=9 July 2017 | accessdate=3 August 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article63105 | title=SPLM-IO Taban faction calls on refugees return to Maiwut State | publisher=''Sudan Tribune'' | date=28 July 2017 | accessdate=3 August 2017}}{{cite web | url=http://www.africanews.com/2017/07/29/south-sudan-army-captures-ethiopia-border-town-held-by-rebels// | title=South Sudan army captures Ethiopia border town held by rebels | publisher=Africanews | date=29 July 2017 | accessdate=3 August 2017}} The government took over Pagak in August 2017 while the IO rebels still held territory in traditional Nuer areas of Panyijar Country in Unity state and rural areas of Jonglei and Akobo state.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-army-capture-rebel-headquarters-near-ethiopia/3975442.html|title=South Sudan Army Capture Rebel Headquarters Near Ethiopia|date=7 August 2017|accessdate=11 August 2017|work=Voice of America}} SPLA-IO counterattacked Taban Deng Gai's SPLA-IO force, in an attempt to retake Pagak.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-idUSKBN1AR0YW|title=Heavy fighting erupts in South Sudan near border with Ethiopia|date=11 August 2017|accessdate=11 August 2017|work=Reuters}} An additional dimension of the conflict became the fighting between the opposition loyal to Machar and those supporting Taban Deng, largely within the Nuer majority former state of Unity. Observers felt that Kiir had given up on negotiations by talking with Taban Deng instead of Machar during the peace talks, as Taban is seen by many in the opposition as a traitor. As part of the "National Dialogue" initiated by Kiir in December 2016 where any former rebels who return to the capital will be given amnesty, about a dozen SPLM-IO officials defected to the government in January 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/south-sundan-defections-splm-splaio-kiir-machar/3681833.html|title=South Sudanese opposition figures defect to Kiir administration|publisher=Voice of America|date=18 January 2017|accessdate=2 February 2017}} Gabriel Tang, who was one of the generals to have defected from Machar during the peace talks in 2015, now allied with [[Lam Akol]]'s largely Shilluk NDM and became its [[chief of staff]].{{cite web|url=http://www.southsudannewsagency.com/index.php/2017/01/07/spla-io-destroys-command-government-linked-rebel-group/|title=SPLA-IO destroys command of government-linked rebel group|publisher=South Sudan News Agency|accessdate=6 January 2017}} In January 2017 Tang was killed in clashes with the SPLM-IO allied Agwelek forces led by [[John Uliny]], a move the SPLM-IO proclaimed as a warning to rival rebel factions. Two days later, Olony's forces ambushed and killed Yohanis Okiech.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article61329|title=Another rebel commander shot dead in war-torn South Sudan|date=7 January 2017|publisher=Sudan Tribune}} [[File:Cirillo.jpg|thumb|left|General Thomas Cirillo of the National Salvation Front (NSF or NAS).]] In February 2017, Deputy head of logistics Lt. Gen. Thomas Cirillo Swaka resigned, accusing Kiir of ethnic bias. This led to a series of high ranking resignations, including minister of Labour Lt. Gen. [[Gabriel Duop Lam]]{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/idAFL4N1G235Q|title=South Sudan general resigns ministerial post, defects to rebels|publisher=Reuters|date=17 February 2017|accessdate=9 March 2017}} who also pledged allegiance to Machar. Swaka formed a new rebel group called the National Salvation Front (NAS or NSF) in March 2017.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/gen-thomas-cirillo-declares-new-rebel-group|title=Gen. Thomas Cirillo declares new rebel group|publisher=Radio Tamazuj|date=6 March 2017|accessdate=6 March 2017}} In March 2017, Cirillo, a [[Bari people|Bari]] from Equatoria, got additional support as SPLM-IO's Western Bahr al Ghazal commander, Faiz Ismail Futur, resigned to joined NAS while there are reports of six SPLM-IO shadow governors from Equatoria defecting to NAS.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/a/new-south-sudan-rebel-group-gains-supporters/3770611.html|title=New South Sudan Rebel Group Gains Supporters|date=17 March 2017|accessdate=17 March 2017|work=Voice of America}} In the same month, head of the Cobra Faction Khalid Boutros dissolved the Cobra Faction and merged it with Gen. Thomas Cirillo's NAS and claimed opposition groups are in consultation to unite their ranks.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/ssdm-cobra-faction-dissolved-merged-cirillos-rebels|title=SSDM-Cobra Faction dissolved, merged with Cirillo's rebels|date=9 March 2017|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}} In July 2017, John Kenyi Loburon, SPLA-IO's commander of Central Equatoria state switched to join NAS,{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-idUSKBN1AD1N4?il=0|title=South Sudan army captures rebel-held town, senior rebel defects|date=28 July 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|work=Reuters}} claiming favoritism towards Nuers in SPLA-IO and then as NAS general in the same month, fought with SPLA-IO in Central Equatoria in the first clashes between the two groups.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest-idUSKBN1AF0JI|title=Fighting between South Sudan rival rebel groups wounds two|date=30 July 2017|accessdate=1 August 2017|work=Reuters}} By November 2017, NAS captured areas in [[Kajo Keji]] from SPLM-IO, before both groups were routed by the government.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/news/article/cirillo-s-group-captures-two-areas-from-machar-s-faction-in-kajo-keji|title=Cirillo's group captures two areas from Machar's faction in Kajo-Keji|date=19 October 2017|accessdate=7 January 2018|work=Radio Tamazuj}} With broad support at its inception, by 2018, many had come to view NAS as simply "the Bari".{{cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/can-us-sanctions-on-south-sudan-rein-in-a-nation-of-warlords/|title=Can US Sanctions on South Sudan Rein in a Nation of Warlords?|date=9 April 2018|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=The Nation}} By March 2018, nine opposition groups, including NAS, NDM, SSPA and SSLM but notably not including SPLM-IO, joined to form the 'South Sudan Opposition Alliance' to collectively negotiate with the government.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-rebel-leaders-form-coalition/4276649.html|title=South Sudan Rebel Leaders Form Coalition |date=1 March 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018|work=Voice of America}} ===Split among ruling Dinka and 2018 peace agreement (2017–present)=== [[File:Paul Malong Awan.png|thumb|right|[[Paul Malong Awan]], former [[South Sudan People's Defense Forces|SPLA]] army chief, rebelled against the government in April 2018 ]] Cracks were appearing along clan lines among the ruling Dinka. Kiir's Dinka of [[Warrap (state)|Warrap]] were in a feud with the Dinka of [[Paul Malong Awan]]'s [[Aweil State|Aweil]], who contributed the bulk of the government's fighting force in the war.{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/opinion/2017/11/15/south-sudan-needs-bold-alternatives-not-dumpster-fire-failed-interventions|title=South Sudan needs bold alternatives, not this dumpster fire of failed interventions|date=15 November 2017|accessdate=7 January 2018|work=Irin News}} Around this time, the largely Dinka [[South Sudan Patriotic Army]] (SSPA) was formed in Northern Bahr el Ghazal, with the backing of powerful figures such as former presidential advisor Costello Garang Ring{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/news/article/costello-s-army-general-group-of-soldiers-defect-to-government-in-aweil|title=Costello’s army general, group of soldiers defect to government in Aweil|date=27 October 2017|accessdate=5 August 2018|work=Radio Tamazuj}} and allegedly Malong Awan. In May 2017, Kiir reduced the power of the chief of staff position{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudan-president-restructures-spla-leadership/3853440.html|title=South Sudan President Restructures SPLA leadership|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=17 May 2017|work=Voice of America}} and fired its powerful Dinka nationalist Malong Awan and replaced him with General [[James Ajonga Mawut]], who is not a Dinka but a [[Luwo people|Luo]].{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-military-idUSKBN18528T|title=South Sudan president replaces army chief|date=9 May 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017|work=Reuters}} Awan left Juba with most of his [[Mathiang Anyoor]] militia{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201705170359.html|title=South Sudan: Why Kiir Had to Fire His Army Chief Malong|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=17 May 2017|work=The East African}} while other militia members reportedly joined SSPA. By the end of 2017, SSPA had claimed to have captured territory around Aweil{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/news/article/rebel-group-claims-capture-of-two-areas-in-northern-bahr-al-ghazal|title=Rebel group claims capture of two areas in Northern Bahr al Ghazal|date=15 June 2017|accessdate=5 August 2018|work=Radio Tamazuj}} and was seen as one of the biggest threats to Juba.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article62752|title=South Sudan army denies rebel capture of military base in Aweil|date=16 June 2017|accessdate=5 August 2018|work=Sudan Tribune}} Awan was accused of plotting a rebellion and was detained but then released following pressure from the Dinka lobbying group, the Dinka Council of Elders.{{cite news|url=http://sudantribune.com/spip.php?article64448|title=South Sudan president says Awan has to return to prove his innoncence|date=8 January 2018|accessdate=11 February 2018|work=Sudan Tribune}} In April 2018, Awan announced the launch of a rebel group named [[South Sudan United Front]] (SS-UF), which claimed to push for federalism.{{cite news|url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/South-Sudan-ex-army-chief-forms-new-rebel-group/2558-4379144-3jnbuaz/index.html|title=South Sudan ex-army chief Malong forms new rebel movement|date=9 April 2018|accessdate=15 April 2018|work=East African}} The United States, after failing in 2016, put additionally pressure on Juba by successfully passing an [[arms embargo]] on South Sudan in July 2018 through UN Security Council, with Russia and China abstaining from voting this time.{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20180713-united-nations-imposes-arms-embargo-south-sudan|title=United Nations imposes arms embargo on South Sudan|date=13 July 2018|accessdate=15 July 2018|work=France24}} Additionally, with neighboring Sudan facing economic troubles and relying on revenue from transporting oil from South Sudan, the Sudanese government, with a mix of incentives and coercion,{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/opinion/international/400368-south-sudans-peace-process-is-broken|title=South Sudan’s peace process is broken|date=5 July 2018|accessdate=5 August 2018|work=The Hill}} brought Kiir and SPLA-IO to hold talks in Khartoum. In June 2018, they signed another ceasefire where they agreed to form a transitional government for the 36 months leading to national elections and to [[African Union]] and IGAD peacekeepers to deploy to South Sudan and state boundaries would be drawn by commission chaired by a non-South Sudanese;{{cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/omar-al-bashir-mediating-south-sudan-peace-talks-180705134746432.html|title=Why is Omar al-Bashir mediating South Sudan peace talks?|date=5 July 2018|accessdate=5 July 2018|work=Al Jazeera}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/24/opinion/south-sudan-peace-agreement.html |title=The Trouble With South Sudan’s New Peace Deal|date=24 September 2018|accessdate=26 September 2018|work=New York Times}} this ceasefire was violated just a few hours after coming into effect, when pro-government forces [[2016–18 Wau clashes#Paul Malong Awan's rebellion and renewed clashes|attacked rebels in Wau State]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/30/world/africa/south-sudan-cease-fire-violated-within-hours.html |title=South Sudan Cease-fire Violated Within Hours |author=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=30 June 2018|accessdate=2 July 2018}} SPLM-IO protested when the Parliament, where the President's party holds a majority of seats, extended the President's term and that of other officials by three years.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-unrest/south-sudan-parliament-extends-presidents-term-until-2021-idUSKBN1K21RD|title=South Sudan parliament extends president's term until 2021|date=12 July 2018|accessdate=15 July 2018|work=Reuters}} However, they eventually agreed to share power again with Machar to be one of five Vice Presidents and the 550 seat parliament to be divided with 332 going to Kiir's faction, 128 to Machar's group and the rest to other groups.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/south-sudans-warring-leaders-agree-to-share-power-again/2018/07/25/6ca19412-902b-11e8-ae59-01880eac5f1d_story.html?utm_term=.f04fa306e745|title=South Sudan's warring leaders agree to share power, again|date=25 July 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018|work=Washington Post}} The South Sudan Opposition Alliance made up of most of the rest of the rebelling militias, rejected the deal citing their small share in the power sharing agreement.{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article65930|title=South Sudan opposition groups reject governance deal, citing poor ratios and referendum |date=25 July 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018|work=Sudan Tribune}} As part of amnesty offered to groups following the peace deal, in August 2018, Brigadier General Chan Garang, claiming to be lead a group of rebel soldiers from Malong's SS-UF, came back to the government along with 300 rebel soldiers in what was seen as a weakening of SS-UF.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/rebel-faction-rejoins-south-sudan-army/4539512.html|title=Rebel Faction Rejoins South Sudan Army |date=22 August 2018|accessdate=25 August 2018|work=Voice of America}} == Atrocities == ===Attacks on civilian centers=== The government is accused by the US and aid groups among others of using starvation as a tactic of collection punishment for populations that support rebels by intentionally blocking aid.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/south-sudans-people-are-starving-and-fighters-are-blocking-aid/2017/03/31/69ef31c2-0f60-11e7-aa57-2ca1b05c41b8_story.html|title=South Sudan’s people are starving, and fighters are blocking aid|date=31 March 2017|accessdate=8 July 2017|work=Washington Post}} Ateny Wek Ateny, president's spokesman told to news conference, claims that rebel troops went into the hospital in the town of [[Bor, South Sudan|Bor]] last month and slaughtered 126 out of 127 patients. Apparently an elderly man was blind and rebels spared him.{{cite web|url = http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-22/244945-south-sudan-accuses-rebels-of-massacring-127-hospital-patients.ashx |title=South Sudan accuses rebels of massacring 127 hospital patients |work=The Daily Star |date= 22 January 2014 | first =Carl | last = Odera}} On January 31, 2014 in violation of the cease fire agreement, the signed Government troops attacked town of Leer in Unity State, forcing 240 Staff and patients of Doctors Without Borders in Leer to flee into the bush. Thousands of civilians have fled to the bush. Doctors Without Borders has lost contact with two thirds of its staff formerly located in Leer.{{Citation | title = South Sudan insecurity at Leer has devastating consequences for those hiding in bush | url = http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org//article/south-sudan-insecurity-leer-has-devastating-consequences-those-hiding-bush | publisher = Doctors without borders}}{{Citation | title = South Sudan: satellites show homes aflame at opposition leaders’ hometown | url = http://www.enoughproject.org/blogs/south-sudan-satellites-show-homes-aflame-opposition-leaders-hometown | publisher = Enough project}} It is believed that the town was attacked by government troops as it is the home of former Vice President Riek Machar.{{Citation | title = South Sudan unrest: attacks on Riek Machar, unity state | url = http://www.voanews.com/content/south-sudan-unrest-attacks-riek-machar-unity-state/1843314.html | publisher = Voice of America}} On 18 April, UN said that at least 58 people were killed and more than 100 others wounded in an attack against one of its bases in South Sudan sheltering thousands of civilians.{{cite news|url=http://dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Apr-18/253786-at-least-58-killed-in-attack-on-un-base-in-south-sudan.ashx#axzz2zFqGR4cf|title=At least 58 killed in attack on U.N. base in South Sudan|work=The Daily Star|date=18 April 2014}} On 17 April 2014, 58 people were killed in an attack on the UN base in [[Bor, South Sudan|Bor]].{{cite news|last=Lederer|first=Edith M|title=UN Says 58 Killed in Attack on UN Base in Sudan|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/58-killed-attack-base-ssudan-23384020|accessdate=18 April 2014|newspaper=abc|date=18 April 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-27074635|title=South Sudan conflict: Attack on UN base 'kills dozens'|date=17 April 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}{{cite news|title=South Sudan attack on UN base leaves dozens injured|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/17/south-sudan-clashes-dozens-injured|accessdate=18 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=17 April 2014|agency=AFP}} 48 of those killed were civilians, while 10 were among the attackers.{{cite news|title=South Sudanese soldiers sent to protect UN base after more than 48 killed|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/apr/18/south-sudanese-soldiers-protect-un-base-48-killed|accessdate=18 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=18 April 2014|agency=Reuters}} UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] emphasised that any attack on UN peacekeepers constituted "a [[war crime]]", while the [[UN Security Council]] expressed "outrage" at the attack.{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Steve|title=Deadly attack on South Sudan base may be considered a 'war crime'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/south-sudan/10775859/Deadly-attack-on-South-Sudan-base-may-be-considered-a-war-crime.html|accessdate=19 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=19 April 2014}}{{cite web|title=Attacks against the United Nations and civilians in South Sudan: Security Council Press Statement|url=http://newyork-un.mae.lu/en/News/Attacks-against-the-United-Nations-and-civilians-in-South-Sudan-Security-Council-Press-Statement|publisher=Permanent Mission of Luxembourg to the United Nations|accessdate=19 April 2014}} In late 2016, in a government attack on [[Yei]], three villages were destroyed with 3,000 homes burned in a single village.{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-sudanese-forces-blamed-torching-thousands-homes/3790837.html|title=South Sudanese Forces Blamed for Torching Thousands of Homes|agency=Voice of America|date=31 March 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017}} ===Ethnic cleansing=== {{Main|Ethnic violence in South Sudan}} {{See also|2014 Bentiu massacre}} There are ethnic undertones to the conflict with the SPLM and SPLA, which have been accused of being dominated by the Dinka. A Dinka lobbying group known as the "Jieng Council of Elders" is often accused of being behind hardline SPLM policies.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/dinka-council-elders-welcomes-kiir’s-decision-firing-ministers-allied-machar|title=Dinka council of elders welcomes Kiir’s decision firing ministers allied to Machar|date=4 August 2016|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article59719|title=Jieng Council of Elders caused "coup" in SPLM-IO: official|date=24 July 2015|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=Sudan Tribune}} While the army used to attract men from across tribes, during the war, the SPLA had largely constituted soldiers from the Dinka stronghold of [[Bahr el Ghazal (region of South Sudan)|Bahr el Ghazal]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/opinion/south-sudan-cannot-be-allowed-to-collapse.html?_r=1|title=South Sudan must not be allowed to collapse|date=20 January 2017|publisher=New York Times}} and the army was often referred to within the country as "the Dinka army". Much of the worst atrocities committed are blamed on a group known as "Dot Ke Beny" (Rescue the President) or "[[Mathiang Anyoor]]" (Brown caterpillar), while the SPLA claim that it is just another battalion.{{cite web|url=http://africanarguments.org/2016/07/11/whos-behind-south-sudans-return-to-fighting/|title=Who's behind South Sudan's return to fighting?|date=11 July 2016|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=African arguments}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39209280|title=South Sudan conflict: 'Soldiers will kill you for no reason in Yei'|first=Alastair|last=Leithead|date=9 March 2017|accessdate=9 March 2017|work=BBC}} Immediately after the alleged coup in 2013, Dinka troops, and particularly Mathiang Anyoor,{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/10/28/report-mass-graves-rape-cannibalism-in-south-sudan.html|title=Mass Graves, Rape Cannibalism in South Sudan|date=28 October 2015|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=Al Jazeera}} were accused of carrying out pogroms, assisted by guides, in house to house searches of Nuer suburbs,{{Citation | title = South Sudan: ethnic targeting, widespread killings | url = https://www.hrw.org/news/2014/01/16/south-sudan-ethnic-targeting-widespread-killings | publisher = Human Rights Watch}} while similar door to door searches of Nuers were reported in government held Malakal.{{Citation|url=https://news.yahoo.com/sudan-troops-39-door-door-39-seized-town-215351156.html |title=Sudan troops go ‘door to door’ in seized town |publisher=Yahoo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140126065608/http://news.yahoo.com/sudan-troops-39-door-door-39-seized-town-215351156.html |archivedate=26 January 2014 |df= }} About 240 Nuer men were killed at a police station in Juba's Gudele neighborhood.{{Citation | title = South Sudan, the state that fell apart in a week | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/23/south-sudan-state-that-fell-apart-in-a-week | date = 2013-12-23 | newspaper = The Guardian | place = [[United Kingdom|UK]]}}{{cite web| first = James | last = Copnall|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25502457 |title=South Sudan sees 'mass ethnic killings' | publisher = BBC|date= 24 December 2013 |accessdate= 24 December 2013}} During the [[South Sudanese Civil War#Renewed conflict and rebel infighting|fighting in 2016-17]] in the Upper Nile region between the SPLA and the SPLA-IO allied Upper Nile faction of Uliny, Shilluk in [[Wau Shilluk]] were forced from their homes and Yasmin Sooka, chairwoman of the Commission on Human Rights in South Sudan, claimed that the government was engaging in "social engineering" after it transported 2,000 mostly Dinka people to the abandoned areas.{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-03-15/un-warns-of-south-sudan-27social-engineering27/8354958|title=South Sudan: UN warns of 'social engineering' amid looming threat of genocide|publisher=ABC news|accessdate=17 March 2017|date=14 March 2017}} The king of the [[Shilluk Kingdom]], Kwongo Dak Padiet, claimed his people were at risk of physical and cultural extinction.{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/south-sudan-experiencing-ethnic-cleansing-un-report-says/415571874/|title=South Sudan experiencing ethnic cleansing, UN report says|publisher=Star Tribune|accessdate=9 March 2017|date=7 March 2017}} In the Equatoria region, Dinka soldiers were accused of targeting civilians on ethnic lines against the dozens of ethnic groups among the Equatorians, with much of the atrocities being blamed on [[Mathiang Anyoor]]. [[Adama Dieng]], the U.N.'s Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide, warned of [[genocide]] after visiting areas of fighting in [[Yei River State|Yei]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-southsudan-uganda-refugees-idUSKBN1441QU|title=Hatred spills beyond South Sudan along with refugees|date=15 December 2016|publisher=Reuters}} Khalid Boutros of the Cobra faction as well as officials of the Murle led [[Boma State]] accuse the SPLA of aiding attacks by Dinka from Jonglei state against Boma state,{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/ssdm-cobra-faction-dissolved-merged-cirillos-rebels|title=SSDM-Cobra Faction dissolved, merged with Cirillo's rebels|date=9 March 2017|access-date=9 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}}{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/gunmen-attack-boma-villages-displaced-residents-official|title=Gunmen attack on Boma villages displaced residents: Official|date=8 March 2017|access-date=12 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}} and soldiers from Jonglei captured Kotchar in Boma in 2017.{{cite news|url=https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/boma-deputy-governor-says-gunmen-jonglei-captured-kotchar|title=Boma deputy governor says gunmen from Jonglei captured Kotchar|date=8 March 2017|access-date=12 March 2017|work=Radio Tamazuj}} The SPLM-IO is predominantly Nuer and its head, Machar, had previously committed the [[Bor massacre]] of mostly Dinka civilians in 1991. In 2014, the [[2014 Bentiu massacre|Bentiu massacre]] occurred when Bentiu was recaptured by rebels April 2014 and 200 people were killed in a mosque. Rebels separated the people and picked out those from opposing ethnic groups who they then executed.{{cite web|author=April 21, 2014 3:57 PM |url=https://news.yahoo.com/sudan-rebels-slaughtered-hundreds-ethnic-massacres-un-115333412.html |title=S.Sudan rebels slaughter 'hundreds' in ethnic massacres: UN – Yahoo News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421190849/http://news.yahoo.com/sudan-rebels-slaughtered-hundreds-ethnic-massacres-un-115333412.html |archivedate=21 April 2014 }} ===Child soldiers=== Since the conflict began, more than 17,000 children were used in the conflict, with 1,300 recruited in 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=55806#.WMVrW0htl1u|title=Number of children recruited into South Sudanese conflict passes 17,000 – UNICEF|agency=UN|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=15 December 2016}} ===Sexual violence=== Reported incidents of sexual violence rose 60% in 2016, with Mundri in Equatoria's [[Amadi State]] being called the epicenter of the problem.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/03/25/rape-reaches-epic-proportions-in-south-sudan-civil-war.html|title=Rape reaches 'epic proportions' in South Sudan's civil war|agency=Fox News|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=27 March 2017}} A UN survey found that 70% of women who were sheltering in camps had been raped since the beginning of the conflict, with the vast majority of rapists being police and soldiers{{cite web|url=http://www.unmultimedia.org/tv/unifeed/asset/1796/1796878/|title=South Sudan emergency session|date=14 December 2016|publisher=United Nations}} and that 80% had witnessed someone else getting sexually assaulted.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/south-sudan-famine-dec-emergency-appeal-women-children-rape-murder-war-crimes-refugees-uganda-a7630201.html|title=Women and children being raped and slaughtered as South Sudan conflict worsens famine threatening millions|date=14 March 2017|accessdate=17 March 2017|publisher=The Independent}} The SPLA were reported to have recruited militias and young men in Unity state to take back rebel held areas. They were given guns and their pay was what they could loot and women they could capture, who were raped.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/sep/28/south-sudan-women-girls-raped-as-wages-for-government-allied-fighters|title=South Sudan:women and girls raped as 'wages' for government-allied fighters|date=28 September 2016|publisher=The Guardian}} ===Violence against UN and foreign workers=== It has been argued that with increased tension with the UN and outside powers over the government's actions there has been a new shift in violence by the government against foreign peacekeepers, aid workers and diplomats.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/10/south-sudans-attacks-on-u-n-could-imperil-future-peacekeeping/|title=South Sudan's Attacks on U.N. Could Imperil Future Peacekeeping|date=10 October 2016|publisher=foreignpolicy}} NGOs are viewed with suspicion, with Minister of cabinet affairs claiming "most of the (humanitarian) agencies are here to spy on the government." During the 2016 Juba clashes, 80-100 South Sudanese troops entered the Terrain hotel facility and [[gang rape]]d five international aid workers, singling out Americans for abuse, with nearby peacekeepers refusing to help the victims.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/06/un-peacekeepers-refused-to-help-south-sudan-rebels-raped-aid-workers-report|title=UN peacekeepers refused to help as aid workers were raped in South Sudan – report|first=Jason|last=Burke|date=6 October 2016|website=the Guardian|accessdate=27 March 2018}} In July, soldiers ransacked a [[World Food Programme]] warehouse, stealing enough food to feed 220,000 people for a month, worth about $30 million. In July, a [[Rocket-propelled grenade]] was fired near a UN peacekeepers' vehicle with two Chinese peacekeepers dying after the government refused passage to a clinic 10 miles away. In December 2016, two staff members of the [[Norwegian Refugee Council]] were expelled from the country without a formal explanation.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/12/14/2nd-norwegian-refugee-worker-expelled-from-south-sudan.html?refresh=true|title=2nd Norwegian refugee worker expelled from South Sudan|publisher=Fox News|date=14 December 2016|accessdate=14 December 2016}} In the deadliest attack on aid workers, six aid workers were killed in an ambush on 25 March 2017 bringing the number of aid workers killed since the start of the war to at least 79.{{cite news|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39400650|title=South Sudan ambush leaves six aid workers dead, UN says|agency=BBC |date=26 March 2017 |accessdate=27 March 2017}} Violence has come from the rebel side as well. On 26 August 2014, a UN [[Mi-8]] cargo helicopter was shot down, killing 3 Russian crew members, and wounding another. This occurred 9 days after rebel commander [[Peter Gadet]] threatened to shoot down UN aircraft, which he alleged were transporting government forces.[https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2014/09/09/un-crashed-helicopter-in-south-sudan-shot-down Helicopter that crashed in South Sudan was shot down after rebel commander issued threat] ''Associated Press''. 9 September 2014. Accessed 12 September 2014 == Casualties == ===Mortality=== During the first two days of fighting after December 15, reports indicated that 66 soldiers had been killed in clashes in Juba,{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/At-least-66-troops-dead-in-South-Sudan-fighting-Doctor/articleshow/27539127.cms |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131224074705/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/At-least-66-troops-dead-in-South-Sudan-fighting-Doctor/articleshow/27539127.cms |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 December 2013 |title=At least 66 troops dead in South Sudan fighting: Doctor |work=The Times of India |date=17 December 2013 |accessdate=24 December 2013 }}{{cite web|url = http://www.ethiomedia.com/14store/5365.html |title= South Sudan: At least 500 killed in fighting | publisher= Ethio media | date= 18 December 2013 |accessdate= 24 December 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25425453 |title=South Sudan clashes 'kill 400–500' after coup claim |publisher=BBC |date=18 December 2013 |accessdate=24 December 2013}} and at least 800 injured.{{cite web|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/21/21996598-four-hurt-as-gunfire-hits-us-military-plane-sent-to-evacuate-americans-from-south-sudan |title=Four hurt as gunfire hits US military plane sent to evacuate Americans from South Sudan |work=NBC News |accessdate=24 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224000653/http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/12/21/21996598-four-hurt-as-gunfire-hits-us-military-plane-sent-to-evacuate-americans-from-south-sudan |archivedate=24 December 2013 |df= }} By 23 December, the number of dead had likely surpassed 1,000 people{{cite news|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/26/us-southsudan-unrest-talks-idUSBRE9BP0AG20131226 |title=UN hopes for South Sudan reinforcements within 48 hours |agency=Reuters |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=26 December 2013}} while an aid worker in the country estimated that the death toll was most likely in the tens of thousands.{{cite web|author=Daniel Howden in Juba |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/dec/23/south-sudan-state-that-fell-apart-in-a-week |title=South Sudan: the state that fell apart in a week |work= The Guardian |accessdate=24 December 2013}} The International Crisis Group reported on 9 January 2014 that up to 10,000 people were estimated to have died. In November 2014, the International Crisis Group estimated the death toll could be between 50,000 and 100,000.{{cite web|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/south-sudan/50000-and-not-counting-south-sudans-war-dead|title=50,000 and not counting: South Sudan's war dead|work=Agence France Presse|date=16 November 2014}} A senior SPLA officer stated in November 2014 that the number of government soldiers killed and wounded topped 20,000, with 10,659 soldiers killed from January to October 2014 and 9,921 seriously wounded, according to a report by Radio Tamazuj.{{Cite news|url = https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/south-sudans-military-casualties-top-20000|title = South Sudan's military casualties top 20,000|last = |first = |date = 2014-11-23|work = Radio Tamazuj|access-date = 2015-10-16|via = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160204182503/https://radiotamazuj.org/en/article/south-sudans-military-casualties-top-20000|archivedate = 4 February 2016|df = dmy-all}} By March 2016, after more than two years of fighting, some aid workers and officials who did not want to speak on the record said the true figure might be as high as 300 000."[http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/south-sudan-is-dying-and-nobody-is-counting-20160311-4 South Sudan is dying, and nobody is counting]". [[News24]]. 11 March 2016. A study by the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine of deaths leading up to April 2018, reported that about 383,000 people are conservatively{{cite news|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/a-new-report-estimates-more-than-380000-people-have-died-in-south-sudans-civil-war/2018/09/25/e41fcb84-c0e7-11e8-9f4f-a1b7af255aa5_story.html?utm_term=.ad420a6e46de|title=A new report estimates that more than 380,000 people have died in South Sudan’s civil war|agency=Washington Post|date=26 September 2018|accessdate=26 September 2018}} estimated to have died as a result of the war, while the actual may be considerably higher, with 190,000 deaths directly attributed to violence and most of the deaths in Jonglei, Unity and Equatoria. Two Indian UN peacekeepers were killed on 18 December when their base was stormed by rebels, and three US military Osprey aircraft were fired upon leading to four American service personnel being wounded.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-25476920 |title=South Sudan evacuation aircraft fired on, US troops hurt | publisher =BBC |date=21 December 2013 |accessdate=24 December 2013}} On 21 January 2014 Ankunda said that 9 [[Uganda]]n soldiers died in a rebel ambush at Gemeza a week ago, and 12 others had been killed in total since 23 December. [[File:Olympic flag.svg|thumb|South Sudanese made up the largest contingent among the [[Refugee Olympic Team]], who competed under the [[Olympic Flag]] (above).]] ===Displaced people=== {{Main|Refugees of South Sudan}} [[File:South Sudan - Displacement snapshot as of March 2017.png|thumb|left|Map showing the [[Refugees of South Sudan|displacement of South Sudanese civilians]] due to the civil war as of March 2017]] More than 4 million people have been displaced, with about 1.8 million internally displaced and about 2.5 million having fled to neighboring countries, especially Kenya, Sudan, and Uganda. This makes it the world's third-largest refugee population after Syria and Afghanistan. About 86% of the refugees are women and children.{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/inpictures/2017/02/atrocities-prompt-mass-exodus-central-equatoria-170211134948079.html|title=Atrocities prompt mass exodus in Central Equatoria|agency=Al Jazeera|date=15 February 2017|accessdate=21 February 2017}} Uganda, which took more refugees in 2016 than all of those who crossed the Mediterranean into Europe,{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/south-sudans-refugees-most-africa-keep-fleeing-violence-continues-556250|title=South Sudan's forgotten refugees keep fleeing as violence continues|agency=Newsweek|date=14 February 2017|accessdate=21 February 2017}} has had a notably generous policy. Refugees are allowed to work and travel and families get a 30-metre by 30-metre plot of land to build a home with additional space for farming. In just six months since being built, the [[Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement]] in Uganda became the single largest refugee settlement on earth.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/jan/24/uganda-sprawling-haven-for-270000-of-south-sudans-refugees|title=Uganda's sprawling haven for 270,000 of South Sudan's refugees|agency=The Guardian|date=24 January 2017|accessdate=26 January 2017}} However, the Ugandan government is seen as an ally of Kiir's crackdown on rebels, although with an increasing refugee population, Uganda has pressured Kiir to make peace.{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/dc855d9a-501c-11e7-bfb8-997009366969|title=Regional leaders pressure South Sudan leader to end conflict|agency=Financial Times|date=13 June 2017|accessdate=15 June 2017}} The largest contingent of the [[Refugee Olympic Team at the 2016 Summer Olympics]] came from South Sudan, including its flag bearer. ===Starvation=== [[File:SouthSudan.jpg|thumb|right|January 2017 map with phase classifications from "minimal" to "famine"]] {{Main|2017 South Sudan famine}} After the second Juba clashes, fighting intensified in the Equatoria region. As this is the agricultural heart of the country, the number of people facing starvation in the already food insecure nation soared to 6 million. In February 2017, famine was declared in Unity state by the government and the United Nations, the first declaration of famine anywhere in the world in six years.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39025927|title=South Sudan declares famine in Unity State|date=20 February 2017|accessdate=20 February 2017|publisher=BBC News}} Days after the declaration of famine, the government raised the price of a business visa from $100 to $10,000, mostly aimed at aid workers, citing a need to increase government revenue.{{cite news|url=https://www.alaraby.co.uk/english/news/2017/3/4/south-sudan-hikes-visa-cost-to-10-000-amid-famine|title= South Sudan hikes visa cost to $10,000 amid famine|publisher=Alaraby|date=5 March 2017|accessdate=6 March 2017}} == See also == {{Portal|South Sudan|2010s|War}} * [[Central African Republic conflict (2012–2014)]] * [[International reaction to the South Sudanese Civil War]] == Notes the crisis in South Sudan | publisher = [[FAO]] | title = Emergencies}}. * [https://www.vice.com/pages/saving-south-sudan Vice – Saving South Sudan] * [https://www.vice.com/the-vice-report/saving-south-sudan-full-length Saving South Sudan Documentary] * [http://www.peaceau.org/uploads/auciss.final.report.pdf ''Final Report of the African Union Commission of Inquiry on South Sudan'' (Oct. 2014)] * [http://www.peaceau.org/uploads/auciss.separate.opinion.pdf ''A Separate Opinion'' by Professor Mahmood Mamdani, Commissioner, Member, African
